label: Ostrich
description: The world’s tallest and heaviest bird, the common ostrich is native to the grasslands and savannas of Africa. These birds are completely flightless but are incredibly swift runners due to their long, strong legs—in fact, they are the fastest two-legged animals on Earth.
fun_facts:
The fastest bird on land, ostriches can sprint up to 43 miles (70 kilometers) per hour. 
	An average ostrich egg weighs around 3 pounds (about the weight of two dozen chicken eggs!)   
	Ostriches have excellent eyesight. In fact, their eyes are bigger than their brains!

label: Hartmann's mountain zebra
description: Native to the rocky slopes and arid plateau areas of southwestern Africa, Hartmann’s mountain zebras are large herbivores known for their black and white-striped coats. Hartmann’s mountain zebras are a rare subspecies of the mountain zebra, which is one of three types of zebras.
fun_facts:
Mountain zebras are the smallest of the zebra subspecies.  
	They are known to be capable climbers, navigating the rocky hillsides of their mountain habitats with ease. 
	When no water is available in their dry habitats, they will use their sharp, pointed hooves to dig for water beneath the ground surface.

label: Red wolf
description: The red wolf is a critically endangered canine native to the southeastern United States. Highly intelligent and sociable animals, red wolves were once abundant throughout their native range, but habitat loss and persecution by humans drove this species to the brink of extinction in the 20th century.
fun_facts:
With just a few hundred individuals remaining, red wolves are among the rarest mammals in the world.
	Despite their fearsome reputation, red wolves are normally quite shy around people. They pose little to no threat around humans.
	Their home territory can stretch about 200 miles in diameter.

label: Puff adder
description: One of the most widespread venomous snakes, puff adders are native to Africa and parts of the Saudi Arabian peninsula. They are named for their habit of puffing themselves up to look larger than they are to deter predators. Rather than fleeing the sound of approaching footsteps as most snakes do, puff adders go still, hiss in warning, and then strike fiercely to protect themselves.
fun_facts:
Though they spend most of their lives on the ground, puff adders are adept swimmers and climbers.
	When scared, puff adders coil into a tight “s” shape. Adults can bite creatures about a third of their length away, but juveniles can launch their entire bodies forward to attack.

label: American oystercatcher
description: This eye-catching shorebird is native to the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of the Americas. True to its name, the American oystercatcher feeds on oysters, saltwater mollusks, shellfish and other marine invertebrates, using its thick red bill to jab at shelled prey and pluck the contents from within.
fun_facts:
American oystercatchers open clams and other prey by quickly jabbing their bills inside the bivalve’s shell and severing the muscle that pulls the shell halves shut. Then they eat the soft parts inside.
	Young chicks will dive and swim underwater to escape predators.
	Their genus name, Haematopus, comes from the Greek words for “blood foot,” referring to the bird’s bright pink legs.

label: Horseshoe crab
description: Living fossils older than the dinosaurs, horseshoe crabs have been on Earth for around 450 million years. They are famous for their enormous breeding swarms, which can involve up to a million crabs at one time.
fun_facts:
Horseshoe crabs walk along the sea bottom, but they can swim using their gills as paddles.
	A chemical called hemocyanin makes their blood blue. This is different from hemoglobin, which makes vertebrate blood blue.
	Horseshoe crabs glow under ultraviolet light.

label: Striped hermit crab
description: Striped hermit crabs are small, greenish-blue crustaceans that are quite common among the warmer parts of the Atlantic Ocean, where they scavenge for food both on land and in the water. Like many species of hermit crabs, they protect themselves from predators and harsh natural elements by spending nearly their entire lives inside the discarded shells of gastropods, like whelk or conch.
fun_facts:
Many species of hermit crab get aggressive when they are ready to switch to a larger shell, but striped hermit crabs will cooperate with other members of their species and exchange shells without getting violent.
	Females are capable of producing up to 180,000 eggs in a single year.
	When they sense danger, they fit their entire bodies inside of their shells to hide.

label: Mummichog
description: An ordinary-looking fish that isn’t ordinary at all, the mummichog is able to withstand vast temperature and salinity shifts as well as tolerate higher levels of pollutants and radiation than many other animals on the planet.
fun_facts:
The mummichog was the first fish in space! Two mummichog fish were flown to Skylab in 1973.
	They belong to a non-formal group of fish called “killifish” likely from the Dutch word “kill” meaning “stream.” Most killifish live in fresh or brackish water.
	“Mummichog” is the Narragansett word for these fish. It means “going in crowds.”
	Mummichogs are vulnerable to a fish parasite called fluke. When it infects fish, it makes them thrash near the surface making them more vulnerable to being eaten by a bird, which is the parasite’s next host.
	Because they are so easy to care for and so flexible, mummichogs are frequently used in laboratory settings.

label: Pumpkinseed
description: Pumpkinseeds are North American freshwater fish that are very similar in appearance to their cousins, the bluegill.
fun_facts:
Pumpkinseeds are an invasive species in Western Europe, where they out-compete native fish. They have been found in Portugal all the way to the southern coast of Ukraine.
	They are also called pond perch, sunfish and punkie.
	They can hybridize with other members of their genus, including bluegill and green sunfish. Such hybrids are sterile and can’t have offspring.

label: Wild turkey
description:
Tall birds with strong legs, wild turkeys are fast fliers and residents of the eastern United States. Wild turkeys were domesticated in Mexico more than 2,000 years ago, although many members of the species remain wild. 

At the Smithsonian's National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute in Washington, D.C., visitors can see a breed of domestic turkey (which is the same species as the wild turkey) called the standard bronze turkey.
fun_facts:
Wild turkeys are one of only two bird species domesticated from the Americas; the other is the Muscovy duck.
	Wild turkeys are an invasive species in New Zealand and Germany.
	Wild turkeys rarely fly more than 100 yards (91 meters) but they can fly quickly – up to 54 miles per hour (88.5 kilometers per hour). They can even swim!
	Benjamin Franklin wanted the wild turkey to be the country’s national bird instead of the bald eagle. He did not get his wish.

label: Southern cassowary
description: The southern, or double-wattled, cassowary is one of three species of cassowary. Impressive and intimidating-looking, these flightless birds are often said to resemble dinosaurs. They are native to tropical rainforests of Australia and New Guinea, where they live solitary lives—but if necessary, they will defend their territory and chase away intruders with their powerful legs and sharp claws.
fun_facts:
Cassowaries have a 5-inch long razor sharp claw on each foot.
	Cassowaries cannot fly, but they are incredible jumpers and can launch themselves up to 7 feet off the ground!
	The cassowary's helmet-like casque is made of keratin, the same material that makes up our hair and fingernails.

label: Ross's goose
description: The smallest of the three white geese species in North America, Ross’s goose is known for its tendency to form flocks of hundreds or even thousands of individuals—sometimes mixing with snow geese.
fun_facts:
About 1 in 10,000 Ross’s geese are “blue morph” geese that have dark brown necks, backs, and shoulders. Scientists aren’t sure why this happens.
	A Ross’s goose looks similar to the closely-related snow goose, but can be differentiated by head coloring: the heads of snow geese are often streaked with yellow from where they root in marshland for roots and tubers, while the heads of Ross’s geese remain white because they graze on surface vegetation instead.
	This species was described to science in 1770, but not formally classified until 1861. Its Arctic nesting grounds were not discovered until 1938.

label: White-throated sparrow
description: A little brown bird with bold, black and white striped crown and a beautiful song. Their distinctive markings help many beginning birdwatchers learn anatomy and identification skills.
fun_facts:
Like most songbirds, white-throated sparrows have two voiceboxes—called syrinxes—rather than one voicebox, or larynx.
	White-throated sparrows occasionally mate and produce hybrids with dark-eyed juncos. The hybrid offspring look like gray, dull white-throated sparrows with white outer tail feathers like juncos.

label: Rufous-collared sparrow
description: This small, black and brown-colored song sparrow is common sight throughout Central and South America, where it can be seen hopping along the ground near roadsides, parks and other urban areas. Their color patterns vary by area, but most can be identified by their namesake reddish-orange patch found on the back and sides of their neck.
fun_facts:
There are 27 different subspecies of rufous-collared sparrows.
	They have different vocalizations depending on where they live, almost like regional accents in humans.
	In Costa Rica, this bird is known as come maíz, or "corn eater."

label: Band-tailed pigeon
description: A large pigeon that resembles its more common cousin, the band-tailed pigeon flies swiftly through the forests of Western North America in large flocks during its annual migration along the Pacific Coast.
fun_facts:
They are the largest North American pigeon.
	They are closest surviving relatives of the passenger pigeon, a formerly abundant bird whose flocks once stretched across North America before being hunted to extinction.
	As with other pigeon species, they feed their hatchlings with "pigeon milk," a white, nutrient-rich substance that parents regurgitate into their babies' mouths.

label: Rose-breasted grosbeak
description: Vividly colored and with sweet and recognizable songs, rose-breasted grosbeaks are one of the more easily spotted bird species, as they prefer forest edges and other places easily accessible to humans. They can be seen hopping along the ground or flying with elegant arcs and shallow swoops.
fun_facts:
Rose-breasted grosbeaks will visit backyard bird feeders, especially for sunflower seeds.
	The male rose-breasted grosbeak is sometimes called the “cutthroat bird” due to the bright scarlet patch along its throat and chest.
	They are in the same family as northern cardinals.
	Female rose-breasted grosbeak females are almost identical to female black-headed grosbeaks; the two species can even interbreed!

label: Ruddy quail-dove
description: Beautiful but shy, this cinnamon-colored forest dove can be seen throughout the tropical regions of the Americas. It can be identified by a light stripe that runs underneath its eye.
fun_facts:
Ruddy quail-doves are members of the pigeon and dove family and are only distantly related to quails. 
	They often prefer to walk on the ground instead of flying.

label: Blue ground dove
description: This forest dove is known for its beautiful powder-blue coloring. The blue ground dove can be found throughout the humid tropical regions of the Americas, where it lives year-round.
fun_facts:
Males have a call that sounds like a loud "boop."
	They are members of the Columbidae family of birds, which includes the common pigeon.

label: Black-throated blue warbler
description: Migratory songbirds with distinct black-and-blue feathers, black-throated blue warblers prefer to live and hunt in dense, shady forests with lots of plant growth. They search the undersides of leaves and shrubs for arthropods and primarily feed caterpillars to their young.
fun_facts:
They are easily identifiable by their buzzy "zoo-zoo-zoo-zee" song.
	Males and females look radically different and were originally described as two separate species.

label: American yellow warbler
description: American yellow warblers are one of North America's most widely-distributed warblers. Male members of this species are often seen singing at the tops of small trees.
fun_facts:
The yellow warbler has more yellow feathers than any other North American warbler.
	The yellow warbler’s “seet” alarm call specifically warns of brown-headed cowbirds, who are notorious nest parasites for warblers and blackbirds. Other birds, particularly the red-wing blackbird, have learned this warning call and the females will rush back to their nests to protect their eggs from being replaced.
	Female yellow warblers can recognize foreign eggs in their nest. In response, they will rebuild a completely new nest on top of all the eggs and the old nest.

label: Sandhill crane
description: One of only two species of cranes native to North America, the sandhill crane is an impressively large bird that can be identified by its bright red forehead and long neck. Once nearly extinct east of the Mississippi River, their populations have rebounded thanks to dedicated conservation efforts. In the winter months, they form huge colonies sometimes numbering in the tens of thousands.
fun_facts:
The "sandhill" part of their name comes from the Sandhill region of Nebraska.
	Fossil records show that sandhill cranes have been around for nearly 2.5 million years.
	They are known to build platform nests out of sticks and plants that float on the water's surface.

label: Tennessee warbler
description: This tiny, yellowish-green songbird sings a three-note series of accelerating chips. Despite its name, these warblers do not breed in Tennessee, and only pass through the state as they embark on their seasonal migration to their breeding grounds in Canada's boreal forest.
fun_facts:
Despite their name, Tennessee warblers only pass through the U.S. state during their annual migration.
	They love eating spruce bedworms, and their populations grow significantly where bedworms are plentiful.

label: Wood thrush
description: Familiar to nature enthusiasts everywhere, the song of the male wood thrush has been called one of the most beautiful sounds that any animal produces. They are braver than many other thrushes, though not as bold as their cousin, the robin.
fun_facts:
Their scientific name translates to “weasel-colored woodland thrush.”
	Other common names for the wood thrush include the swamp angel, song thrush, or wood robin.
	The wood thrush is the official bird of Washington, D.C.
	Wood thrushes sometimes pick up ants and rub them on their feathers, an activity called “anting.” Scientists aren’t sure why they do this. Some of the ants’ secretions may help protect them from other insects, or it might supplement the birds’ own preen oil.

label: Redhead
description: These handsome diving ducks are a common sight in the northern prairies of the United States and Canada, where they fly each year to breed among semi-permanent ponds and wetlands. As pochards, or diving ducks, they are specially adapted for propelling themselves underwater in search of aquatic plants, small gastropods and mollusks to eat.
fun_facts:
Redheads can be parasitic brooders. They are known for dropping their eggs in another duck’s nest and leaving their ducklings to be hatched and raised by the other duck. 
	Unlike many other migratory ducks, redheads tend to fly with erratic shallow wingbeats in groups of unorganized patterns.
	While considered a diving duck, redheads will sometimes forage for their food on the water’s surface, like a dabbling duck.

label: Green mantella
description: Similar to the small, brightly-colored poison frogs of South America, mantellas are native to the forests and streams of Madagascar. For many years, scientists thought mantellas of Madagascar were closely related to South America’s poison frogs, which they resemble. However, recent genetic research has shown they are only distantly related but have evolved similar coloration and survival strategy.
fun_facts:
A group of mantellas is called an army.
	For many years, scientists thought mantellas of Madagascar were closely related to South America’s poison frogs, which they resemble. However, recent genetic research has shown they are only distantly related but have evolved similar coloration and survival strategy.

label: Sanderling
description: Famous from innumerable trips to the seaside as well as Pixar’s short film Piper, sanderlings are the most prevalent sandpiper in the world. On almost any gentle, sandy beach, the little birds you see running back and forth are probably going to be sanderlings.
fun_facts:
Sanderlings are the only sandpiper with only front-facing toes and no back toes.
	After foraging up and down sandy beaches, sanderlings sometimes vomit up little sand pellets containing small pieces of shells.
	They are often likened to clockwork toys because of their energetic movements up and down beaches chasing waves.
	Sandpipers in the genus Calidris are often called “peeps” because of the sound they make.

label: Short-billed dowitcher
description: Despite its name, the short-billed dowitcher has a bill twice the size of its head. It’s a short bill only compared to its relative, the long-billed dowitcher. The two species were, until recently, considered one species. The main difference between them is the slight difference in beak length and the dramatic difference in their songs and calls.
fun_facts:
While feeding, they rapidly plunge their long bill in and out of the mud, an action that has been compared to a sewing machine.

Their Latin name translates, approximately, to “gray marsh racer.”

label: Northern shoveler
description: The northern shoveler is an easily recognizable duck due to the shovel-shaped bill that inspired its name. Their bill, one of the largest of any waterfowl, is specialized for skimming the water’s surface for small invertebrates and aquatic plants.
fun_facts:
This duck’s shovel-like bill is lined with comb-like projections called lamellae that allow it to sift through marsh waters for tiny crustaceans and seeds. 
	These ducks can be seen swimming together in large circles. This is done to stir up the sediment at the bottom of ponds of lakes and unearth tiny animals like crustaceans. 
	Unlike many species of ducks, northern shovelers are seasonally monogamous. Once a pair bond is formed, they will remain together until the birds leave the breeding grounds in the fall.

label: Southern lesser galago
description: Also called the Moholi bushbaby, southern lesser galagoes are small, tree-dwelling members of the primate family that can be found throughout forested savannah areas of southern Africa. They rely on their huge eyes, strong hands and long tails to move quickly through the trees at nighttime.
fun_facts:
They have some of the largest ears relative to their body size of all primates. Their ears can move independently! 
	They have special bacteria in their stomachs that allows them to digest tree gum more easily. 
	Galagoes are one of the species that practices urine-washing—they urinate into their hands and rub it on their hands and feet. They do this during social grooming, while exploring a new territory, and it may even improve their grip while climbing.

label: Grasshopper sparrow
description: Found in prairies, grasslands and fields, the grasshopper sparrow’s tan and brown coloration allows it to camouflage even in wide open areas.
fun_facts:
Grasshopper sparrows are one of the new North American sparrows where males have two different songs: one song sounds more like an insect buzz while the other is a series of squeaky notes that males emit while in flight.
	The grasshopper sparrow prefers to run along the ground rather than fly. It can be very hard to find unless it is singing.

label: Black-capped chickadee
description: A striking and easy to identify bird, chickadees have a reputation for being chatty busybodies. They are frequent visitors to feeders and backyards and are one of the most studied and well-recognized wild songbirds in North America.
fun_facts:
The call for which they are named in English — "chick-a-dee-dee-dee" — is far more complex than it sounds, with information encoded in each note. Generally the more “dees” that ring out, the greater the threat a predator poses.
	They hide seeds and other foods to eat later, and can remember thousands of individual hiding places.
	Flocks have a dominance hierarchy. Some individuals even belong to several flocks, each with a different ranking.

label: Yellow-rumped warbler
description: The most abundant warbler in North America, the yellow-rumped warbler is an opportunistic omnivore that frequents balsam fir forests in the breeding grounds. Formerly two species, the myrtle warbler in the east and the Audubon warbler in the west, interbreed and hybridize. Ongoing genetic research may split them back into two species.
fun_facts:
They will come to bird feeders for sunflower seeds, raisins, fruit, suet and even peanut butter.
	Birders lovingly call the bird “butter-butt” due to their primrose-hued posteriors.
	The more colorful males tend to forage higher in trees than females.
	Its scientific name means “crowned moth-eater.”

label: Scarlet tanager
description: This small songbird is one of many migratory birds found in North America. Adult males in spring and summer develop a striking red coloration, while females and nonbreeding males are olive-colored. They are one of the most difficult birds to find as they move high within dense forest canopies.
fun_facts:
Their song sounds like that of the American robin's, but with a sore throat.
	The scarlet tanager's genus name, Piranga, comes from the Tupi word tijepiranga, which describes an unknown small bird.

label: Ruby-throated hummingbird
description: The tiny ruby-throated hummingbird is notable for its brilliant, jewel-like red and green coloring. It is the only North American hummingbird species to breed east of the Great Plains.
fun_facts:
Their feet are so small that they cannot walk. They are only capable of scooting sideways on perches.
	They can beat their wings more than 50 times per second!
	During their seasonal migration, they can fly straight across the Gulf of Mexico in a single flight.

label: Northern pintail
description: One of the most widespread duck species, northern pintails have extensive migratory routes. Habitat loss poses the biggest threat to this duck. As their wetland and prairie habitats are converted and fragmented, northern pintail populations continue to decrease.
fun_facts:
Sometimes referred to as the northern nomads, northern pintails have extensive migratory routes and have been spotted on every continent except Antarctica.
	Their slender bodies and 3-foot wingspan allow them to fly great distances at speeds reaching up to 65 miles per hour. This earned them the nickname “the greyhound of the skies.”

label: Green-winged teal
description: Male green-winged teals are easily recognizable for their wide, dark green stripe on their heads. In North America, they are the smallest dabbling duck, or ducks that primarily eat from the surface of the water instead of diving.
fun_facts:
They are smallest duck in North America to primarily eat from the water’s surface instead of diving. This technique is known as dabbling.
	These ducks are one of the fastest-flying ducks in North America. The fastest recorded green-winged teal hit a speed of 60 miles per hour!
	Courtship among green-winged teals occurs in large groups and, at times, up to 35 males may court a single female.  
	They have some of the most elaborate mating “dances” of all ducks.

label: Canvasback
description: Canvasbacks are North America’s largest diving ducks. Their common name is derived from the breeding male’s canvas-colored white body. When selecting their wintering grounds, they look for large bodies of water with large amounts of submerged aquatic vegetation.
fun_facts:
The canvasback was given its common name by early European settlers, who described the male ducks as having a canvas-like color. 
	This duck’s scientific name was derived from its preferred food: celery root. Celery root’s scientific name is Valisineria americana and the canvasback’s is Arthya valisineria.
	They are swift and agile fliers, although they need to get a running start to lift off the ground.

label: Bufflehead
description: Buffleheads are small diving ducks that have large, rounded heads. They are often found in ponds and small lakes, but also use salt water in coastal areas during the winter.
fun_facts:
Buffleheads are North America’s smallest diving duck.
	These ducks appear to have a large head relative to their small size, which is how they got their name, “bufflehead.”

label: Blue-winged teal
description: A bit of a warm-weather duck, blue-winged teals seem to spend more time on their wintering grounds in Central and South American than any other dabbling duck in the Americas. These small dabbling ducks are often seen in pairs or small groups at the edges of ponds and lakes.
fun_facts:
The blue-winged teal is one of the latest species to migrate north in the spring but one of the first to head back south in the fall.
	Females will choose their nest site by landing in a grassy area and walking around. It can take up to two days before she will find a place suitable to start building her nest.

label: Blue grosbeak
description: A small bird with a big bill, the blue grosbeak is a North American songbird with a striking deep-blue color. Found throughout much of the southern United States, their rich, warbling song can be heard around thickets and hedgerows during the breeding season. Sometimes they will pop up to a high perch to flick and spread their tails.
fun_facts:
They are often confused with the indigo bunting. However, blue grosbeaks are larger and have chunkier bills.
	They are close relatives of the Northern cardinal.

label: Black-bellied whistling duck
description: This tall-standing duck has a long neck and gangly legs. One of only two types of whistling duck found in the Americas, it is becoming more common in the southern United States, where it flies each year to breed.
fun_facts:
It has a soft, wheezy whistle that almost sounds like a squeaky toy with several following notes.
	The black-bellied whistling duck is monogamous, pairing with the same mate for many years.

label: Song sparrow
description: A familiar sparrow that can be found throughout North America, song sparrows are often seen singing cheerfully while perched on a tree branch or telephone wire.  The species is present in most of their range year-round, although northern populations migrate to the southern United States and Mexico for the winter.
fun_facts:
Their color patterning varies based on what region they are from. Southern song sparrows tend to be paler brown, while northern and coastal residents have dark brown and black streaks in their feathering.
	There are 24 different subspecies of song sparrows.

label: Cedar waxwing
description: North American birdwatchers can easily recognize these sociable, fruit-eating birds. With their distinctive silky-smooth plumage, handsome black mask, and buzzy, high-pitched calls, cedar waxwings are often encountered in orchards, farm fields, and other places with lots of fruit-bearing trees and bushes.
fun_facts:
Cedar waxwings specialize in eating fruit. While they do need protein from insects, their diet is almost entirely fruit-based in winter.
	They are called ‘waxwings’ because some of them produce waxy, bright red appendages on the tip of their secondary wing feathers. The number of waxy tips vary by age and sex, but researchers do not know their purpose.
	Cedar waxwings have been observed eating overripe berries that have fermented in the sun, which causes the birds to become intoxicated.

label: Red knot
description: Red knots are large, stocky shorebirds known for their rusty red plumage during the breeding season. As champions of long-distance migration, many individuals fly nearly 19,000 miles annually between their breeding and wintering grounds.
fun_facts:
Some red knots fly over 9,000 miles one-way to get to their coastal wintering grounds in the south. In the spring, they make the same journey north!
	The rufa red knot subspecies stops in the Delaware Bay every year during spring migration to feed on horseshoe crab eggs. These eggs give the birds the fuel they need to reach their breeding grounds in the north.

label: Yellow-breasted chat
description: The yellow-breasted chat is a large North American songbird that migrates seasonally. Despite their bright coloring, they are often hard to spot, since they spend much of their time among thick tangles of vegetation.
fun_facts:
This bird has a feeding habit that's unique among songbirds: it grips its food with its feet before eating.
	For a long time, ornithologists considered this bird to be a member of the warbler family. Scientists aren't totally sure how closely related they are.

label: American robin
description: One of most common bird species in North America, American robins can be heard singing their cheerful melody in diverse habitats, from deep forest interiors, to rural pastures, to city parks and backyard gardens. They are thought of as the "bringers of spring," due to the species' reputation for flying south for the winter and traveling northward during the springtime.
fun_facts:
American robins are actually members of the thrush family. Despite sharing a name, they are only distantly related to European robins.
	American robins are often thought of as having reddish-orange chests. However, one subspecies in Mexico has a chest that is pale grayish-brown.

label: Black-throated green warbler
description: This small, greenish-yellow songbird can be found among the boreal, or forests of the northern U.S. and Canada, singing its buzzy "zee-zee-zee-zooo-zeet" song from the treetops.
fun_facts:
Adult males sing a song that sounds like "zee-zee-zee-zooo-zeet" while courting females.
	They use a similar sounding "zoo-zee-zoo-zoo-zee" song while challenging other males who enter their territory.
	Their genus name, Setophaga, comes from the Greek words for "moth" and "eating." This is because warblers tend to eat lots of insects.

label: Black-and-white warbler
description: This beautifully black-and-white streaked warbler is a migratory bird of the Americas. It can be found singing its high-pitched song as it travels from its warm wintering grounds of Central and northern South America up to the forested breeding grounds of eastern North America.
fun_facts:
Their squeaky song almost sounds like a rusty wheel turning.
	This bird is sometimes called the "black-and-white creeper," due to its habit of creeping along branches while searching for insects to eat.

label: Swainson's thrush
description: This sweet-singing forest bird travels across the Americas each year to reach its northern breeding grounds. It is known for its ascending, flute-like song.
fun_facts:
Another name for this bird is the “mosquito thrush,” due to their feeding habit of snatching insects out of the sky mid-flight.
	Six different subspecies of Swainson’s thrushes have been recognized.

label: Black-necked stilt
description: Black-necked stilts are a tall, medium-size shorebird with black-and-white coloration, long pink legs, a long neck, and a straight black bill. They spend most of their days gracefully darting along shorelines and wetlands and wading in shallow water.
fun_facts:
To defend their nests, black-necked stilts will perform a “popcorn display,” in which a group of birds surrounds the predator and individual birds hop, jump and flop to confuse and drive it away.
	In relation to body size, they have the longest legs compared to any other bird aside from flamingoes. 
	Black-necked stilts and American avocets belong to the same family and are capable of producing young together. Those who have documented this cross-hybridization have termed the offspring as “avo-stilts.”

label: American avocet
description: The American avocet is a large, migratory shorebird that forages for food in wetlands, marshes, tidal flats and shallow lakes and ponds. They have long bluish legs, a long neck and a thin, long, upturned black bill.
fun_facts:
The plumage on their head and neck changes with the seasons. During the breeding season, the feathers turn a rusty orange color, but in the winter, they are grayish white.
	Female avocets sometimes lay their eggs in the nests of other female avocets, otherwise known as brood parasitism. These "host" female avocets will incubate the eggs and rear the hatchlings as if they were their own.
	Adults have long, upturned black bills. Males tend to have less of a curve compared to females.

label: Ruddy turnstone
description: The ruddy turnstone is a short legged, chunky sandpiper with an extensive wintering range. Turnstones are known for sticking their bills under stones, pebbles and shells, and flipping them over to find food.
fun_facts:
As a migratory bird, they fly huge distances from their breeding grounds to their wintering sites. Some have been known to travel 6,500 miles.
	They are fast travelers, flying at speeds averaging 27-47 miles per hour.
	They use their beaks to flip over rocks and shells to look for food. Sometimes several birds work together to flip larger objects.

label: Common yellowthroat
description: This small, chunky songbird has a summer range that stretches across the United States and Canada. Males and females look different, but they both have the eye-catching yellow throat coloring that give the species its name.
fun_facts:
In parts of the Midwest, this bird is called the yellow bandit.
	Males sing their wichety wichety wichety wich song to establish territory and attract females.
	Like many other warblers, they migrate mostly at nighttime.

label: Baltimore oriole
description: This brilliantly-colored orange and black songbird has a clear, flute-like whistle that varies based on the individual. Common in forests and fields in eastern North America during spring and summer. Females build bag-shaped nests that hang from tall, leafy trees.
fun_facts:
Baltimore orioles look similar to an orchard oriole, but there's an easy way to tell them apart: Baltimore orioles have vibrant orange coloring on their bellies, while orchard orioles are more of a chestnut brown.
	Baltimore orioles get their name because their coloring resembles the coat-of-arms of the 17th century Lord Baltimore.
	There is a famous Major League Baseball team named after this bird.

label: Carolina wren
description: If you are in the eastern United States and encounter a bird that looks like a little brown check-mark with a loud voice, it’s probably a Carolina wren. These charismatic little birds have loud, distinctive songs and are frequent visitors to backyards and bird feeders.
fun_facts:
There are seven recognized subspecies of Carolina wren.
	They belong to the Troglodyte family which means “cave dweller.” They don’t necessarily live in caves, though they do nest in tree cavities.

label: Orchard oriole
description: Similar in coloration and closely related to the Baltimore oriole, the orchard oriole is the smallest member of the New World blackbird family that includes red-winged blackbirds and meadowlarks.
fun_facts:
They are generally not aggressive toward other species. They nest near Baltimore orioles, robins, chipping sparrows and kingbirds.
	They don’t tend to visit backyard seed feeders but will sometimes visit nectar feeders or those with fruits and jelly.
	When they fly, they tend to stick close to the ground, never flying above the tree canopy.

label: Red-eyed vireo
description: This small songbird is a common sight among the leafy woodlands of North America during the spring and summer months. It is noteworthy for its ruby-red irises and persistent singing.
fun_facts:
The name "vireo" comes from a Latin word meaning "I am green."
	Only adults have the red eye color that gives this species its name. Juveniles have brown eyes.
	According to Guinness World Records, the red-eyed vireo holds the record for most number of songs per unit time for a bird species, with 22,197 songs recorded in a 10-hour period.

label: Red-winged blackbird
description: One of North America’s most abundant birds, red-winged blackbirds are named for the signature red patch on the males’ shoulder. Only northern populations migrate south, joining with other birds to form enormous flocks.
fun_facts:
Winter flocks can comprise several million birds, including other blackbird species and starlings.
	Intruders beware! These birds are territorial. Male red-winged blackbirds will chase out intruders of any size if they wander too close to a nest.

label: Barred parakeet
description: Native to the Americas, the barred parakeet (also known as the lineolated parakeet) is a small, green member of the parrot family. It lives year-round in the humid tropical highland forests near the equator. Their small, green bodies make them quite difficult to spot in their native forested habitat, so they are more often heard flying overhead rather than seen.
fun_facts:
Barred parakeets form flocks of hundreds of individuals that often fly above mountain clouds.
	They are often kept as pets because of their even-tempered and sociable natures.
	They are especially fond of bamboo seeds.

label: White-eyed vireo
description: One of hundreds of species of birds that flies across the North American continent each year, the white-eyed vireo can be heard singing its tune from thickets and shrubs in northern and eastern North America during the spring and summer. Its pale white irises are notable, as are the distinct yellow "spectacles," or rings, that surround its eyes.
fun_facts:
Not all white-eyed vireos migrate. Some populations that live in the southern parts of the U.S., especially around the Gulf Coast, stay there year-round.
	Juvenile members of this species actually have dark gray eyes. They do not develop white irises until they reach adulthood.
	There are six subspecies of white-eyed vireo.

label: Rufous-crowned sparrow
description: Distinguished by the red feathers on top of its head, the rufous-crowned sparrow is a year-round resident of the rocky hills of the American Southwest and the central interior of Mexico. It moves slowly throughout its territory, searching in small groups for insects and seeds to eat, often while walking or running on the ground.
fun_facts:
The word rufous comes from the Latin word for "red."

Rather than flying, they spend much of their time walking or running on the ground in search of food.

label: Ovenbird
description: A small bird with a loud song, the ovenbird is a migratory songbird that passes through much of North America in the spring and fall.
fun_facts:
Ovenbirds gets their name from the dome-shaped nest that it builds, which resembles a mud oven.
	Unlike many other warblers, ovenbirds walk on the forest floor, rather than hop, while looking for food.

label: Northern mockingbird
description: Known for its impressive and loud vocalizations, the northern mockingbird is an intelligent bird that can mimic the songs of many other birds.
fun_facts:
A male may learn around 200 songs throughout its life.
	Both males and females sing a varied, repetitive song that can be heard all day—and sometimes all night—during the spring and summer.
	They can incorporate non-bird noises they hear into their songs.
	Mockingbirds are very territorial. They will chase off much larger animals, including humans, if they think their nests are being threatened.

label: Semipalmated sandpiper
description: A very small wading bird, semipalmated sandpipers are one of the most common sandpipers. They are a familiar sight to beachgoers as they dart about in the waves. Their name, “semipalmated,” means they have partially webbed feet.
fun_facts:
During migration, some semipalmated sandpipers double their weight, so they can have enough energy to fuel their long-distance migrations.
	Some semipalmated sandpipers make nonstop flights over the Atlantic Ocean from the northeast coast of North America to South America, a distance of up to 2000 miles (about 3200 kilometers).

label: Ruddy duck
description: Ruddy ducks are thick-necked diving ducks that can be found in wetlands and lakes across North America. When males are in breeding plumage, they sport bright blue bills and deep chestnut bodies.
fun_facts:
Males court females by splashing in the water and blowing bubbles with their bills.
	During the summer months, adult males sport deep brown feathers and a bright blue bill.

label: Indigo bunting
description: Noted for their beautiful blue coloring among breeding males, the indigo bunting is a member of the cardinal family. These migratory birds are often heard singing in fields and farmlands in late spring and summer.
fun_facts:
Like other migratory species indigo buntings migrate at night, using the stars for navigation!
	They often build their nests near roadsides, power lines and train tracks.

label: Magnolia warbler
description: Small, strikingly colored songbirds, magnolia warblers can be found across the Eastern United States as they migrate to and from their breeding grounds in the spring and fall.
fun_facts:
They frequently join foraging flocks of chickadees during their migration. The “chickadee-dee-dee” call is a possible marker for the presence of the magnolia warbler.
	Ornithologist Alexander Wilson first recorded the magnolia warbler in 1811. He named the species after the magnolia tree that he found it in, even though they prefer other types of trees.

label: Dunlin
description: Dunlins are a medium-sized sandpiper with a slightly down-curved black bill. In North America, dunlins spend the summer breeding season in the arctic and subarctic regions, and winter along both coasts of the United States and Mexico.
fun_facts:
The name "dunlin" comes from its winter plumage, a dull brown-gray color often called dun. As far back as 1531, they were called “dunling,” which means “little brown one.”
	Dunlin flocks can fly up to 45 to 55 miles (72 to 88 kilometers) per hour.

label: Gray catbird
description: A cousin of the mockingbird, these medium-sized gray songbirds are common across the warmer parts of North America, where they are frequently heard (but less often seen) in backyards and parks. They often return to the same summer territory year after year.
fun_facts:
Their ability to mimic vocalizations of other species may help males impress mates. A bird with a big vocabulary would have survived several years and, therefore, would make a good mate.
	Catbirds’ calls are often confused with cats’ meows.
	Their genus name, Dumetella, means “little thicket” in Latin, and reflects where they like to live.

label: American wigeon
description: American wigeons are small ducks that are equally at home on land and in the water. Loud, gregarious and distinctive, more than 2.5 million wigeons live in North America.
fun_facts:
Occasionally vagrant Eurasian wigeons will show up in the middle of a flock of American wigeons.
	American wigeons have been known to follow other diving ducks to steal away their food, leading to them sometimes being called robber ducks or poacher ducks.

label: Semipalmated plover
description: Semipalmated plovers are small, plump shorebirds with a short bill, long orangish legs, and a single black "necklace" of feathers. They travel across North America each year to their remote sub-Arctic nesting grounds.
fun_facts:
The name "semipalmated" comes from their partially-webbed toes.
	Their bill is incredibly strong. They sometimes use it to hammer into rocky sand and gravel to probe for food.

label: Palm warbler
description: This small, fairly common songbird travels between cool, boggy northern forests and warm southern regions each year. Unlike many of their warbler cousins, they are often seen foraging on the ground, not in trees, while bobbing their tail.
fun_facts:
The Eastern sub-species is called the yellow palm warbler and in the spring it migrates east of the Appalachian mountains, while the Western palm warbler migrates through the Mississippi Valley.
	Despite their name, palm warblers do not actually build their nests in palm trees. Their name is associated with the palm trees of Hispaniola, the Caribbean island where the earliest specimens were collected.
	They bob their tails up and down while foraging for food.

label: Pygmy slow loris
description: Often described as resembling children’s teddy bears, pygmy slow lorises have large, round, forward-facing eyes. Their small size makes them almost invisible in dense forests.
fun_facts:
Pygmy slow lorises are the only known venomous primate. Modified sweat glands near their elbows allow pygmy slow lorises to secrete a toxin. When they’re alarmed, they can lick these glands, spreading the toxin to their teeth. Their venom can incapacitate predators as large as humans.
	Pygmy slow lorises sleep curled up in a ball with their head between their knees and their legs hooked over their head.
	Their large eyes give them phenomenal vision, even in dim light in a forest. In fact, bright light can be hugely disorienting and distressing for them.

label: Eastern screech-owl
description: “WHOOO are you?” Eastern screech-owls are commonly found in evergreen and deciduous forests in both urban and rural areas, mostly near water. They are short, stocky owls with gray or reddish-brown feathers and yellow eyes.
fun_facts:
Eastern screech-owls can rotate their heads 270 degrees. They have 14 vertebrae in their necks (humans have only 7)!
	They have asymmetrical ear openings. One ear is higher than the other to help them pinpoint sound.
	These owls are opportunistic eaters. If they think they can eat it, they will try.

label: Pallas' cat
description: Pallas’ cats resemble small, stocky, long-haired domestic cats. They live in rocky, dry, scrubby areas throughout Central Asia. Their long, dense hair makes them look stockier than they are but keeps them warm in cold weather. Pallas’ cats have short legs and are slow runners. They rely on camouflage and their low-slung bodies to hunt and to stay safe from predators, including snow leopards, wolves and eagles.
fun_facts:
Most cats have vertical slit-like pupils, but Pallas’ cats have round pupils.
	When they are excited or scared, they make a sound much more like the yelp of a small dog than any typical cat sound.
	When Pallas' cats were first discovered, some naturalists mistakenly thought they were the wild ancestors of domestic Persian cats, because they look so alike.

label: Binturong
description: Due to their nature and habits, binturongs are often hard to spot in the wild. They are nocturnal, meaning they sleep during the day and are active at night. They live in trees but rather than jump, they climb to the ground to cross from one tree to another. They can climb facedown by gripping trees with their semi-retractable claws and strong, prehensile tails that grasp like an extra limb. They are classified as carnivores but mainly eat plants.
fun_facts:
They are often described as smelling like buttered popcorn because their urine contains 2-acetyl-1-pyrroline, the chemical compound that gives popcorn its aroma.
	Baby binturongs are called binlets.
	They have extremely long tails which they use to balance when moving along tree limbs.  They use their tails to grasp branches and even to lower themselves.

label: Collared brown lemur
description: Collared brown lemurs, also known as collared lemurs or red-collared brown lemurs, are native to southeastern Madagascar and named for their collars of reddish-brown fur.
fun_facts:
Their lower teeth form a "tooth comb," which they use to groom their hair.
	They eat fruit and help disperse fruit seeds around the forests where they live.

label: Northern snakehead fish
description: Northern snakehead fish are native to China, Southern Siberia and North Korea and are an invasive species in North America.
fun_facts:
Northern snakeheads have sacs above their gills that absorb and store oxygen from air, allowing them to survive out of water.
	Snakeheads can also "walk" on land, moving their head and back fin in opposite directions to propel them forward.
	Snakehead fish are carnivores with dagger-like teeth, making them dangerous predators.

label: Spiny-tailed monitor
description: Spiny-tailed monitors are small lizards found in Northern Australia. Their appearance is often likened to that of a miniature Komodo dragon.
fun_facts:
Pale stripes on the spiny-tailed monitor's neck distinguish it from two similar-looking subspecies that occupy the same range.
	It can defend itself with its spiny tail, which can be wielded like a club.

label: African plated lizard
description: There are 30 species of plated lizards, and the African plated lizard (also called the giant plated lizard) is one of the largest. It has a squat body, plate-like scales and powerful legs.
fun_facts:
When threatened, these lizards will hide inside the cracks of rocks and fill their lungs with air to wedge themselves in place.
	Their eggs are large with leathery shells.

label: Spotted Pond Turtle
description: Spotted pond turtles live in the northern region of the Indian subcontinent in the Indus and Ganges river drainages. They are named for the white or yellow spots on their heads, legs and tails.
fun_facts:
When they retreat into their shells, spotted pond turtles make a soft croak.
	They can grow up to 16 inches long.

label: Madagascar Giant Day Gecko
description: Brightly colored Madagascar giant day geckos are native to eastern Madagascar. Adhesive scales on their toes help them cling to smooth surfaces.
fun_facts:
Geckos are the only lizards that produce more than a hiss or other simple sound. Their vocalizations range from squeaks and clicks to barks and croaks.
	Adhesive scales, called lemellae, on a day gecko's toes help it cling to smooth surfaces.

label: Iranian Fat-tailed Gecko
description: Iranian geckos are lizards found in semi-desert or semi-arid mountainous regions of northeastern Syria, northern Iraq, west-central Iran, and Turkey.
fun_facts:
The Iranian gecko can detach its tail to distract a predator while it makes an escape.
	When frightened, the Iranian gecko will push itself onto the tips of its toes and hiss or squeal.

label: Guinea pig
description: Guinea pigs are rodents that were first domesticated in 5,000 B.C.  The domesticated species, Cavia porcellus, is most likely derived from the Andean Cavia tschudii (or montane guinea pig), found in Peru, highland Bolivia, northwestern Argentina, and northeastern Chile.
fun_facts:
Guinea pigs have no tails.
	Only about 4% of their day is spent sleeping, and they only sleep for about 6 minutes at a time.

label: Crocodile Monitor
description: Crocodile monitors are large, arboreal lizards from southeast Asia. They have black-green bodies with patters of bright yellow spots and stripes and can weigh up to 44 pounds.
fun_facts:
Scientists can look at hormones to determine whether a crocodile monitor is male or female.
	The crocodile monitor can use its powerful tail like a whip for defense.

label: Emperor tamarin
description: Emperor tamarins are small monkeys native to the southwest Amazon Basin. They are easily identified by their long, white whiskers that look like a mustache.
fun_facts:
It is believed that emperor tamarins were named after German emperor Wilhelm II.
	Their long, white whiskers resemble a mustache.

label: Home's hinge-back tortoise
description: The Home's hinge-back tortoise is a small tortoise found throughout the coastal regions of the Gulf of Guinea in Western Africa. Its distinct shell angles down at the back.
fun_facts:
Home's hinge-back tortoises require high humidity, which is unusual compared to most other tortoise species.
	They mostly eat insects, which is also unique to this tortoise species.

label: African pancake tortoise
description: The African pancake tortoise — also known as the crevice tortoise, softshell tortoise and Tonier’s tortoise — has a thin, flat shell. It is native to East Africa and found in Kenya, Tanzania, and Zimbabwe.
fun_facts:
Pancake tortoises have thin, flat shells.
	They seem to get most of their water from the foods they eat.

label: Chameleon forest dragon
description: Chameleon forest dragons have green or brown bodies with orange and tan markings. Despite their name, they are not true chameleons but can still change color to blend into their habitat.
fun_facts:
Despite their name, these lizards are not true chameleons.
	They are insectivorous, meaning they eat insects.

label: Tomistoma
description: The tomistoma, also called the false gharial or false gavial, is an endangered freshwater crocodilian with a characteristically long, narrow snout.
fun_facts:
A male tomistoma can grow to be 16 feet long!
	There's no evidence to suggest that tomistoma parents care for their young after they hatch, which is unusual for crocodilians.

label: Smallwood's anole
description: The Smallwood's anole is a green lizard with blue spots. It is native to Cuba, where it spends time hunting the trees for insects, grubs and frogs.
fun_facts: Males have a colorful flap of skin underneath their chin, called a dewlap, which they can extend to appear larger and more threatening.

label: Timber rattlesnake
description: The timber rattlesnake — also called the American viper, black rattlesnake, eastern rattlesnake, timber rattler and canebrake — is a large pit viper with a wide distribution across the eastern half of the U.S.
fun_facts:
Timber rattlesnakes are skilled climbers and have been discovered in trees at heights of more than 80 feet.
	They have many common names throughout their range, including American viper, black rattlesnake, eastern rattlesnake, timber rattler and canebrake

label: Alligator lizard
description: Alligator lizards are endangered reptiles native to the Mexican states of Veracruz and Pueblo. These bright blue-green lizards live in trees and eat insects.
fun_facts:
Alligator lizards typically live 130 feet above the forest floor.
	Males tend to have more vibrant colors than females.

label: Corals and sea anemones (anthozoa)
description: The class Anthozoa (under the phylum Cnidaria) includes corals, anemones, sea pens and seafans. Anthozoa consists of 10 orders and thousands of species. Adults are attached to the seabed, but their larvae are free-floating and can drift to new settlements.
fun_facts:
It is estimated that most coral reefs are between 5,000 and 10,000 years old, with some actually tracing their beginnings back 50 million years.
	Coral reefs form as live polyps built not only on each other, but also on the skeleton remains of previous corals. As a result, they are able to create massive structures like the Great Barrier Reef.
	A colony can grow to hundreds of thousands of individual polyps.

label: Boa constrictor
description: Boa constrictors are nonvenomous snakes found in Central and South America. They are named after their mode of predation: constriction.
fun_facts:
Of all the boas, constrictors can live in the greatest variety of habitats.
	They are named for their method of predation: constriction.

label: Wood duck
description: Wood ducks are primarily found in eastern North America, as well as some parts of western North America. They have crested feathers on their heads. Males have iridescent green, blue and purple feathers, as well as two white lines that run from the bill around their red eyes to the back of their head.
fun_facts:
The wood duck's home range changes with the rise and fall of floodwaters.
	The duck's young remain in the nest for just 24 hours after hatching.

label: Hawk-headed parrot
description: The hawk-headed parrot is a colorful bird found in South American rainforests. When frightened, it can raise its neck feathers, forming a fan around its head. These parrots are intelligent and creative, with the ability to solve puzzles when foraging for their food.
fun_facts:
When scared or excited, the hawk-headed parrot can raise its nape feathers, forming a fan around its head.
	They are much smaller than other common Amazonian parrots.

label: Impressed tortoise
description: Impressed tortoises live in evergreen and bamboo forests in hills and mountains across Asia. They have a somewhat flattened shell with a strongly serrated edge and are named for the shape of their scutes, which are impressed or indented.
fun_facts:
These tortoises are named for the shape of their scutes, which are impressed or indented.
	They spend most of their time under leaves on the forest floor.

label: Chinese three-striped box turtle
description: Chinese three-striped box turtles, also called golden coin turtles, were once common across southern China. Today, this critically endangered species is only found in Hong Kong.
fun_facts:
Chinese three-striped box turtles are semi-aquatic.
	Three dark stripes on its shell give it its common name.

label: Perdido Key Beach Mouse
description: Perdido Key beach mice are a critically endangered subspecies of oldfield mice. They have small bodies, hairy tails, relatively large ears and protuberant eyes.
fun_facts:
There are eight subspecies of beach mice, five of which live along the Gulf Coast.
	Beach mice are monogamous and pair for life.

label: Northern Luzon giant cloud rat
description: Northern Luzon giant cloud rats are timid, forest-dwelling animals with a coat of long, rough fur. They are endemic to the island of Luzon in the Philippines.
fun_facts:
The giant cloud rat's large hind feet and long claws make it an excellent climber.
	It is endemic to the island of Luzon in the Philippines.

label: Rhinoceros snake
description: The rhinoceros snake gets its name from the scale-covered protuberance on the tip of its snout.
fun_facts:
The rhinoceros snake gets its name from the scaly "horn" on the tip of its snout.
	In rare instances, a rhinoceros snake will keep its steel gray, subadult coloring rather than turning the typical blue-green.

label: Taylor's cantil
description: The Taylor's cantil, also called the ornate cantil, is a member of the viper family found in the northeastern part of Mexico. This venomous snake is dark brown to black with white, orange or yellow bands. It also has white stripes accented with orange or yellow along both sides of its head and mouth.
fun_facts:
Juvenile Taylor's cantils have a yellow-tipped tail for luring prey. Adults lose this feature.
	These snakes lose their coloration, becoming darker as they age.

label: Chinese crocodile lizard
description: This semiaquatic lizard is found only in China and Vietnam. It is gray-brown with red-orange markings along its throat and sides. Two rigid rows of scales along its tail give this reptile a crocodilian appearance.
fun_facts:
Chinese crocodile lizards frequently enter into a metabolic pause, where they remain motionless and unresponsive to stimuli for several hours at a time.
	This reptile is sometimes referred to as the "lizard of great sleepiness" by indigenous people.

label: Australian snake-necked turtle
description: Australian snake-necked turtles, sometimes called common or eastern long-necked turtles, are named for their long, narrow necks. This semi-aquatic turtle is dark gray or brown with a yellow underside and is native to southeastern Australia.
fun_facts:
Australian snake-necked turtles are named for their long, narrow necks!
	These turtles burrow under fallen leaves and estivate, or become dormant, when conditions get too hot or dry.

label: Eastern box turtle
description: The eastern box turtle, a subspecies of the common box turtle, has a dark brown, hinged shell with yellow-orange markings. When threatened, it can pull its head, tail and limbs inside and shut its shell for protection.
fun_facts:
Eastern box turtles are the official reptiles of Tennessee and North Carolina. They were nearly the state reptile of Pennsylvania as well.
	
	Box turtles generally live for 25-35 years but have been known to survive to over 100 years old!

label: Bennett's wallaby
description: Bennett's wallabies, sometimes called red-necked wallabies, are medium-sized marsupials found along the eastern coast of Australia, and on the island of Tasmania. They are members of the macropod family, which also includes kangaroos and wallaroos.
fun_facts:
Though they may be best known for hopping, wallabies, kangaroos and wallaroos can also crawl and swim!
	In general, wallabies tend to be smaller than kangaroos and wallaroos and can be distinguished by their darker muzzle and paws.

label: Fly River turtle
description: The Fly River turtle, or pig-nosed turtle, is the last living member of the Carettochelyidae family of turtles. With flipper-like forelegs, webbed hind legs and a shell covered in soft, leathery skin, it is well adapted to aquatic life.
fun_facts:
Fly River turtles are also called pig-nosed turtles, because of their large, fleshy snouts.
	Similar to soft-shelled turtles, leathery skin covers the Fly River turtle's shell.

label: Banded rock rattlesnake
description: The banded rock rattlesnake is a venomous species native to parts of the southern United States and Mexico. It is light gray with dark, gray-black bands along the length of its body.
fun_facts: Banded rock rattlesnakes use venom to subdue their prey before swallowing it whole.

label: Corn snake
description: Corn snakes are slender, orange or brownish-yellow snakes with a pattern of large, red blotches outlined in black down their backs. They are native to the eastern United States but are most abundant in Florida and the southeastern U.S.
fun_facts:
Corn snakes are constrictors, wrapping themselves around prey to squeeze and subdue it before swallowing it whole.
	The name corn snake may have originated from the markings on this snake's belly, which resemble maize, or Indian corn.

label: Eastern diamondback rattlesnake
description: The eastern diamondback rattlesnake is North America's longest, heaviest venomous snake, averaging 3-6 feet long, with some adults growing up to 8 feet. It's known for its iconic rattle and its venomous bite, which can be fatal to humans.
fun_facts:
The eastern diamondback rattlesnake is North America's longest, heaviest venomous snake!
	Light reflected off of this snake's keeled scales makes its skin appear dull, rather than shiny.

label: Goeldi's monkey
description: Goeldi's monkeys are small primates with shaggy black hair, claw-like nails and long tails. They inhabit areas of the Amazon rainforest across southern Colombia, eastern Ecuador and Peru, western Brazil and northern Bolivia.
fun_facts:
Goeldi's monkeys can reportedly leap a horizontal distance of about 13 feet without losing height.
	Unlike any other New World monkey, Goeldi's are known to rely heavily on mushrooms during the dry season when fruit is scarce.

label: Meller's chameleon
description: The Meller's chameleon, sometimes called the giant one-horned chameleon, is mainland Africa's largest chameleon species. This bright green and yellow lizard grows to lengths of 2 to 2 1/2 feet (61 to 76 centimeters). Like all chameleons, its eyes can move independently.
fun_facts:
Chameleons can move each eye independently.
	Meller's chameleons can extend their tongues up to 20 inches (51 centimeters) to catch prey.

label: Virginia opossum
description: The Virginia opossum is the only marsupial found north of Mexico. It has a long, prehensile tail and short legs with sharp claws.
fun_facts:
A female can give birth to a litter of four to 25 joeys that are each about the size of a kidney bean.
	Opossums are known for playing dead when they feel threatened, but this behavior is more typical of young opossums.

label: Green aracari
description: The green aracari is a tropical bird named for its dark green back, wing and tail feathers. Its large bill is bright red, yellow and blue with a serrated edge.
fun_facts:
The green aracari's bill has a serrated edge.
	Green aracaris are named for the dark green feathers found on their backs, throughout their wings and into their tails.

label: Green aracari
description: The green aracari is a tropical bird named for its dark green back, wing and tail feathers. Its large bill is bright red, yellow and blue with a serrated edge.
fun_facts:
The green aracari's bill has a serrated edge.
	Green aracaris are named for the dark green feathers found on their backs, throughout their wings and into their tails.

label: Electric eel
description: The electric eel is a knifefish and is more closely related to catfish and carp than to other eel families. This electric fish can generate up to 800 volts of electricity!
fun_facts:
The electric eel is a knifefish and is more closely related to catfish and carp than to other eel families.
	They are capable of generating up to 800 volts of electricity!

label: Northern pine snake
description: The northern pine snake is a powerful, nonvenomous constrictor found in North America. With a maximum length of 6 feet (1.8 meters) it is one of the largest snakes on the continent.
fun_facts:
The northern pine snake is an efficient digger and spends a significant amount of time in underground burrows.
	These snakes reach a maximum length of about 6 feet (1.8 meters).

label: Tentacled Snake
description: The tentacled snake is an aquatic snake easily identified by the pair of short, scaly appendages that extend from the front of its snout.
fun_facts:
Two short, scaly tentacles extend from this snake's snout, giving it its common name.
	This aquatic species herds passing prey by "bumping" out part of its body. The resulting bow wave causes the prey to change course, often heading straight toward the snake's mouth.

label: Sinaloan milksnake
description: The Sinaloan milk snake is a colorful, solitary species rarely seen during the day. Its coloring consists of broad red bands separated by smaller black and yellow bands. Despite its name, the milk snake is a carnivore.
fun_facts:
Sinaloan milk snakes exhibit aposematic mimicry; they are not venomous, but their color patterns resemble those of a venomous snake.
	The common name "milk snake" originated from the false belief that these snakes milked cows.

label: Mangrove snake
description: The mangrove snake is a slender black snake with narrow, yellow bands along its body and around its face. This nocturnal species spends its days coiled among mangrove branches in riverine forests or overhanging coastal waters.
fun_facts:
The mangrove snake has rear fangs and is mildly venomous.
	The mangrove snake's eyes are large with narrow, vertical slits, earning it another common name—the yellow-ringed cat snake.

label: Caiman lizard
description: The caiman lizard is a semi-aquatic species named for its large, heavy scales that resemble those of the caiman crocodile. It has a green body and a reddish-orange head.
fun_facts:
This lizard is named for its large, heavy scales that resemble those of the caiman crocodile.
	Caiman lizards can both climb and swim to escape predators.

label: False water cobra
description: The false water cobra is one of the larger, more abundant snakes inhabiting South America's floodplains. When threatened, this semi-aquatic species can flatten its neck, resembling a cobra, to make itself appear larger.
fun_facts:
This species is named for its ability to flatten its neck to appear larger, resembling a cobra.
	The false water cobra is semi-aquatic and can climb, burrow and swim.

label: Tomato frog
description: Tomato frogs are aptly named for their striking colors. Females are a bright red-orange and males a yellow-orange. In some instances, they have black spots along their backs. These frogs can release a toxic secretion through their skin when threatened.
fun_facts:
These frogs spend much of their time burrowed under leaves and mud.
	They can inflate themselves to deter predators.

label: Northern red salamander
description: Red salamanders are stout-bodied amphibians that range from purplish brown to crimson red, with dark spots and dashes along their backs. Their projectile tongues can extend and return within milliseconds, and they possess toxic-secreting glands to repel predators.
fun_facts:
Red salamanders can extend and withdraw their projectile tongues in 11 milliseconds.
	They have glands that produce a toxic secretion to repel predators.

label: New Caledonian gecko
description: The arboreal and nocturnal New Caledonian gecko is the largest known gecko species, growing to lengths of about 14 inches and weighing 8 to 12 ounces. It is a vocal lizard that produces an array of sounds, including grumbles and growls. New Caledonian geckos have the ability to detach—and later regenerate—their tails when threatened.
fun_facts:
New Caledonian geckos are the largest known gecko species.
	When threatened, these geckos can detach (and later regenerate) their tails.

label: Matamata turtle
description: The matamata is a South American turtle with a striking appearance. Its carapace, or shell, is rough and knobby, and its long neck has skin fringes, bumps and ridges. The matamata turtle's large, flat head features a wide mouth and a long, snorkel-like snout.
fun_facts:
Matamata turtles prefer the soft, muddy bottoms of slow-moving, shallow bodies of water.
	Despite being an aquatic species, matamatas are not well adapted for swimming in open water.

label: Matamata turtle
description: The matamata is a South American turtle with a striking appearance. Its carapace, or shell, is rough and knobby, and its long neck has skin fringes, bumps and ridges. The matamata turtle's large, flat head features a wide mouth and a long, snorkel-like snout.
fun_facts:
Matamata turtles prefer the soft, muddy bottoms of slow-moving, shallow bodies of water.
	Despite being an aquatic species, matamatas are not well adapted for swimming in open water.

label: Lance head rattlesnake
description: The lance head rattlesnake is native to Mexico. This snake's colors range from tan or brown to gray and sometimes white, with an orange-brown stripe down its back. The dark spots along its body are unique to this species of rattlesnake.
fun_facts:
The snake's rattling sound is created through the rapid vibration of a series of loose-fitting, interlocking scales at the base of the tail.
	Lance head rattlesnakes yield a fairly large amount of venom per bite—about 80 to 100 milligrams.

label: Fiji banded iguana
description: Fiji banded iguanas are bright green lizards found only on the Fiji islands. Males have wide blue or light green stripes, while females are typically solid green but may have a few white or pale blue spots.
fun_facts:
Fiji banded iguanas are arboreal and spend most of their time in trees.
	These lizards are named for the blue or light green stripes that males exhibit.

label: Asian water dragon
description: Asian water dragons are bright green lizards found in Thailand, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Burma and southern China. They are adept climbers and strong swimmers. If necessary, they can remain submerged for up to 25 minutes.
fun_facts:
Asian water dragons are strong swimmers and, if necessary, can remain submerged for up to 25 minutes.
	Males and females sometimes express aggressive behavior toward each other in the form of arm waving, puffing up of the throat, head bobbing and chasing.

label: Giant leaf-tailed gecko
description: Leaf-tailed geckos are nocturnal, forest-dwelling lizards endemic to Madagascar and its oceanic islands. Their bodies are long and flattened, and they are known for their leaf-like tails.
fun_facts:
Fringed flaps on the leaf-tailed gecko's sides and lower jaws flatten against a surface, obscuring their outline. The increased surface area reflects and refracts light, aiding their camouflage capabilities.
	If disturbed, the leaf-tailed gecko opens its jaws wide, exposing a bright red mouth and emitting a loud distress call that resembles a child's scream.

label: Emerald tree monitor
description: The emerald tree monitor, or green tree monitor, is a dark jade to lime green lizard found on New Guinea and adjacent islands. This arboreal reptile uses its long claws and prehensile tail (which is twice as long as its body) to grip tree branches while climbing.
fun_facts:
Green tree monitors reach lengths of about 3 feet, with tails twice the length of their bodies.
	Females reportedly use termite mounds as nesting chambers, because the temperature and moisture conditions create an ideal incubator.

label: Green crested basilisk
description: Of the four basilisk species, the green crested basilisk is the most brightly colored. These lizards can sprint on their hind legs. Their speed and specialized scales on their feet allow them to run across the water's surface for several yards before diving underwater where they can remain submerged for more than 10 minutes.
fun_facts:
Basilisks can run on their hind legs. Their speed, coupled with specialized scales on their feet, allows them to sprint across the water's surface.
	Green crested basilisks can remain submerged underwater for more than 10 minutes.

label: Alligator snapping turtle
description: Alligator snapping turtles are the largest freshwater turtles in the world. Their heavy heads, strong jaws and hooked beaks give them a prehistoric appearance, and their carapace, or shell, is spiked.
fun_facts:
Alligator snapping turtles are the largest freshwater turtles in the world.
	An appendage on the alligator snapping turtle's tongue resembles a worm, helping this ambush predator lure prey.

label: White-nosed coati
description: White-nosed coatis are small mammals native to North, Central and South America, from Arizona to Argentina. They have strong claws and long, highly mobile snouts well adapted for foraging in crevices and holes for food. Their thick, semi-prehensile tails are used for balance and often held erect above the body.
fun_facts:
Coatis have been called "coatimundi" or "coati-mondi" meaning "lone coati" in Guarani, a native language of Brazil. The name came about as a result of biologists describing solitary male coatis that they believed at the time to be a separate species.
	The coati's semi-prehensile tail is used for balance and is often held erect above the body.

label: Persian onager
description: The Persian onager is one of the four subspecies of the Asiatic wild ass (the most horse-like ass species) native to the desert of Iran. In comparison to other wild asses, the Persian onager is slightly smaller with a paler coat. Its other common names include the Asiatic wild ass, the Persian wild ass and the Persian zebra.
fun_facts:
The Persian onager is the largest subspecies of Asiatic wild ass.
	Even though their native habitat can reach an incredibly hot 120 degrees Fahrenheit, these hardy animals can adapt to bitter cold temperatures by growing a dense, curly winter coat.
	Ancient civilizations attempted to domesticate the onager without success due to the animal's unruly nature. The onager's relative, the African wild ass, is the ancestor of domestic donkeys.

label: White-naped crane
description: White-naped cranes are an elegant species native to Northern Mongolia, southern Siberia, Korea, Japan and central China. They are slightly smaller than red-crowned cranes. The white-naped crane has a white nape and vertical gray stripes on its neck, as well as a distinct red patch surrounding its eyes.
fun_facts:
The white-naped crane is a popular symbol of the Korean New Year celebration and commonly featured in art and folklore.
	Cranes are the tallest of all flying birds and are found on every continent, except Antarctica and South America.

label: Red siskin
description: The red siskin is a small, vibrantly colored, red and black finch. Though once common throughout the foothills of northern Venezuela, sightings of this vibrantly colored bird are now extremely rare as its population has drastically declined.
fun_facts:
Red siskins were deliberately hybridized with domestic canaries in the early twentieth century to create the "red factor" variety of canary. 
	The red siskin's vocalization a series of trills and chatters with a raspy jut-jut call.

label: Red-crowned crane
description: The red-crowned crane is one of the world's largest cranes. It is a highly aquatic species that feeds in deeper water than other cranes.
fun_facts:
The red-crowned crane is named for the red "cap" on top of its head, which is exposed red skin. These cranes are considered sacred in Japan, where they are considered a sign of fidelity in marriage.
	On average, red-crowned cranes are the heaviest crane species, weighing up to 25 pounds.

label: Guam kingfisher (sihek)
description: The Guam kingfisher is a medium-sized bird (roughly the size of a robin) with a large head and strong beak. It is an aggressive bird that establishes and defends nesting territories, and it has a loud, raspy, distinct call. This species was once found only on the island of Guam but is now extinct in the wild. To the CHamoru people, this species is known as "sihek".
fun_facts:
The Guam kingfisher utters its first call of the morning at about the same time every day, usually at dawn. It does this with such regularity that, according to local belief, the bird can be used to tell time.
	This bird makes its nest in a tree by jabbing repeatedly at the tree's bark with its sharp beak while flying.

label: Loggerhead shrike
description: The loggerhead shrike is a songbird slightly smaller than a robin. Despite its small stature, the behaviors of a shrike reflect those of a raptor. It is commonly known as the "butcherbird" or "thorn bird" for its habit of impaling prey on sharp objects, such as thorns and barbed wire fences.
fun_facts:
The upper edge of the loggerhead shrike's hooked bill features a pair of pointy projections, called "tomial teeth." Like a falcon, the shrike tackles prey with a precise attack to the nape, probably using these "teeth" to paralyze the animal with a jab to the spinal cord.
	Loggerhead shrikes eat the heads and abdomens of toxic lubber grasshoppers but discard the insect's poisonous thorax.
	Newly fledged loggerhead shrikes perform exaggerated, misdirected versions of adult hunting behavior. They peck at inanimate objects, fly about with leaves or sticks in their beaks, practice aerial chases without a target and perform rudimentary impaling gestures.

label: Hooded crane
description: The hooded crane is one of the smallest cranes but, at about 3 feet tall, is still a large bird. It has a dark gray body with a white head and neck, except for a patch of bare red skin above the eye. As with all cranes, hooded cranes form lifelong monogamous pair bonds. These mated pairs engage in unison calling, which is a complex and extended series of coordinated calls.
fun_facts:
The hooded crane's latin name, Grus monacha, translates to "nun crane."
	Hooded cranes nest in such remote forested wetlands in southeastern Siberia that it was not until 1974 that biologists located the first nest.
	Fossil records place cranes in Nebraska more than 9 million years ago.

label: Guam rail (ko’ko’)
description:
