The Guam rail is a flightless but fast-running bird with a narrow body adapted for running through thick marsh grass, weeds and underbrush. Guam rails are secretive, territorial birds that are most easily observed bathing or feeding along roadsides or field edges. To the CHamoru people, this species is named ko’ko’.

They have a loud, screeching call that is a piercing kee-yu whistle or a series of short kip whistles. The call is typically given by two or more birds in response to loud noise, the call of another rail or other disturbances. Guam rails were once considered extinct in the wild. However, populations have been established on Rota and Cko’ko’ocos Island near Guam, and the bird is now listed as critically endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.
fun_facts:
Guam rails can only fly about 3 to 10 feet (1 to 3 meters) at a time.
	In their native Guam, these birds are called ko'ko'.

label: Eld's deer
description: The Eld’s deer, also known as the brow-antlered deer, is an endangered species indigenous to Southeast Asia. The species was discovered in the Manipur Valley of India in 1838 by Lieutenant Percy Eld, a British officer.
fun_facts:
Male Eld's deer are offered large jolly balls during rutting season. They spend a lot of time pushing the balls around with their antlers, much like they would trees and shrubs in the wild. 
	Eld's deer breeding season is triggered by day length. The deer breed in the spring when day length increases, unlike white-tailed deer that breed in the fall as day length shortens.

label: Patagonian mara
description: Patagonian maras are long-legged rodents with bodies similar to hoofed animals. Their coats — which are stiff, dense and very fine in texture — are primarily gray-brown, with a white patch along the chest and stomach and orange coloration around the flanks and head. Their long ears, short tails and larger size set Patagonian maras apart from other species within the family Caviidae.
fun_facts:
Patagonian maras may walk, hop in a rabbit-like fashion, gallop or stot — a unique form of locomotion typically exhibited by ungulates, where the animal bounces on all fours.
	These maras travel in mated pairs, with the male aggressively protecting his mate from rivals and predators.

label: Grand Cayman blue iguana
description: Grand Cayman blue iguanas — also called blue iguanas, Cayman Island blue iguanas or Grand Cayman iguanas — are large, heavy-bodied lizards with colors ranging from gray to bright blue. These ground-dwelling reptiles are diurnal and will bask in the sun to warm up at the start of the day. They can be a territorial species, especially with iguanas of the same sex.
fun_facts:
These heavy-bodied lizards are the Grand Cayman’s largest native land vertebrate.
	This species of “rock iguana” can exceed 5 feet (1.5 meters) in length (nose to tail tip) and weigh more than 25 pounds (11 kilograms).

label: Orangutan
description: Orangutans are the largest arboreal mammals and the most socially solitary of the great apes. All three orangutan species — Bornean, Sumatran and the newly discovered Tapanuli — are critically endangered, primarily due to habitat loss.
fun_facts:
Orangutan means "person of the forest" in the Indonesian and Malaysian languages.
	Orangutans have cognitive maps, often returning to the same feeding sites they have visited in the past to forage for fruit, insects and flowers.
	The primary locomotion of an orangutan is known as "arboreal clambering."

label: Poison frogs
description:
Poison frogs (also called poison arrow frogs, poison dart frogs and dendrobatids), are the most brightly colored frogs in the world. They live in wet, tropical forests in Central and South America where their diet contributes to the toxins they secrete through their skin.

Three species are on exhibit at the Smithsonian's National Zoo: the green and black poison frog, the tri-colored poison frog and the blue poison frog.
fun_facts:
Poison frogs are commonly called poison arrow and poison dart frogs due to the indigenous community reportedly rubbing their arrow tips on the frogs' backs before hunting. However, only three species have been documented as actually being used for this purpose, including the golden poison frog, the most toxic of all frog species.
	All three of these documented species belong to the genus Phyllobates and not Dendrobates, the genus that includes the most brightly colored of poison frogs that are most often recognized as "poison dart frogs."

label: Poison frogs
description:
Poison frogs (also called poison arrow frogs, poison dart frogs and dendrobatids), are the most brightly colored frogs in the world. They live in wet, tropical forests in Central and South America where their diet contributes to the toxins they secrete through their skin.

Three species are on exhibit at the Smithsonian's National Zoo: the green and black poison frog, the tri-colored poison frog and the blue poison frog.
fun_facts:
Poison frogs are commonly called poison arrow and poison dart frogs due to the indigenous community reportedly rubbing their arrow tips on the frogs' backs before hunting. However, only three species have been documented as actually being used for this purpose, including the golden poison frog, the most toxic of all frog species.
	All three of these documented species belong to the genus Phyllobates and not Dendrobates, the genus that includes the most brightly colored of poison frogs that are most often recognized as "poison dart frogs."

label: Tanagers
description: Blue-gray and silver-beaked tanagers are colorful birds native to South America. They primarily eat fruit and insects.
fun_facts: The word tanager comes from the Brazilian Tupi Indian word "tangara."

label: Freshwater stingray
description: Freshwater stingrays live in the Amazon River system and are one of the only rays inhabiting freshwater rather than saltwater. Though docile animals, they are responsible for more injuries to humans each year than any other Amazonian species.
fun_facts:
A stingray's spine is constantly being shed and replaced. At times, they may even have two at a once.
	Although docile creatures, they inflict more human injuries yearly than any other animal in Amazonian rivers.
	Individuals in a litter of stingrays are called pups.

label: Red-crested cardinal
description: The red-crested cardinal is a medium-sized bird that resembles North America's northern cardinal in shape, but is mainly gray with only a brilliant red head, crest and breast. It is native to Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, and is also a common sight in Hawaii and Puerto Rico, where it has been introduced.
fun_facts:
The red-crested cardinal has been featured on postage stamps in its native countries of Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay.
	It is a common sight in Hawaii and Puerto Rico, where it has been introduced.

label: Silver arowana
description: A long fish native to the Amazon drainage system, silver arowanas, sometimes called the "bony-tongued fish" are related to primitive fishes.
fun_facts:
Arowanas are related to primitive fishes and are sometimes called the "bony-tongued fish." "Osteoglossum" means "bony tongue" and "bicirrhosum" means "two barbels."
	Male fish help care for their young by carrying eggs, larvae and early juveniles in their mouths until the yolk sac has been absorbed, which takes about two months.

label: Two-toed sloth
description: Two-toed sloths, also called Linné's or Linnaeus's two-toed sloths, have coarse fur, long limbs and big, curved claws. They live in the tropical rainforests of Central America and northern South America, and spend most of their time in the tree canopy
fun_facts:
Despite being nearly immobile on the forest floor—they drag their bodies across the ground—they are surprisingly competent swimmers.
	Food remains in their relatively short digestive tract for about one month.
	Their metabolisms are so slow that sloths typically only defecate once a week, lowering themselves to the base of their tree to do so.

label: Two-toed sloth
description: Two-toed sloths, also called Linné's or Linnaeus's two-toed sloths, have coarse fur, long limbs and big, curved claws. They live in the tropical rainforests of Central America and northern South America, and spend most of their time in the tree canopy
fun_facts:
Despite being nearly immobile on the forest floor—they drag their bodies across the ground—they are surprisingly competent swimmers.
	Food remains in their relatively short digestive tract for about one month.
	Their metabolisms are so slow that sloths typically only defecate once a week, lowering themselves to the base of their tree to do so.

label: Sunbittern
description: The sunbittern is an elegant bird with long features and plumage decorated in orange, brown and white. Native to tropical habitats in Guatamala and northern Brazil, they are typically found in lowlands, foothills and well-wooded banks of streams and creeks.
fun_facts:
If a predator approaches a nest of baby chicks, one of the parents will pretend to have a broken wing to distract the hunter.
	The oldest sunbittern on record (at any North American zoo) lived until age 33 and was on exhibit in Amazonia at the Smithsonian's National Zoo.
	The sunbittern is the only member of the Eurypygidae family.

label: Twig catfish
description: Twig catfish, named due to their resemblance to twigs, are found throughout the Amazon, Orinoco and Panara rivers, as well as rivers of the Guyana Shield. They are one of the only fish known that have evolved to eat wood as a primary energy source.
fun_facts:
Consuming wood as a primary energy source is extremely rare among vertebrates. Fish in the genus Farlowella are the only known fish evolved to do this.
	They do not attempt to hide their eggs in caves or crevices, instead opting to lay them in open water. Males guard fertilized eggs.

label: Yellow-spotted Amazon river turtle
description: A long-lived turtle native to the Amazon River, only the males and juvenile females have yellow head markings. They are considered vulnerable due to hunting, but the indigenous Yekuana Indians, who eat these turtles and their eggs, are now trying to hunt the turtles sustainably.
fun_facts: Yellow-spotted Amazon River turtles can live up to 70 years.

label: Yellow-spotted Amazon river turtle
description: A long-lived turtle native to the Amazon River, only the males and juvenile females have yellow head markings. They are considered vulnerable due to hunting, but the indigenous Yekuana Indians, who eat these turtles and their eggs, are now trying to hunt the turtles sustainably.
fun_facts: Yellow-spotted Amazon River turtles can live up to 70 years.

label: Red-footed tortoise
description: The red-footed tortoise is found throughout South America and on the Caribbean islands of Trinidad and Barbados. These long-lived tortoises have bright red, yellow or orange patches on their legs, tail and head.
fun_facts:
Males compete for breeding access to females, and fights sometimes result in one male turning another over on to their backs.
	They frequently reach ages of 50 years or more.
	Males and females use head movements as signals to identify each other.

label: Red-bellied piranha
description:
True to their name, red-bellied piranhas are red on their undersides from chin and cheeks to belly. They are important scavengers in their Amazon River ecosystems, and a large part of their diet comes from fins nipped from the tails of larger fish. 

They can grow to be a little over a foot long (30.5 centimeters) and weigh up to 4 pounds (1.81 kilograms). They tend to travel in schools of 20 or more individuals.
fun_facts:
Piranhas play an important role in their natural environment. As both predators and scavengers, their presence in an ecosystem can affect the distribution of other species of fish.
	A good portion of their diet consists of fins nipped from the tails of larger fish.

label: Goliath bird-eating tarantula
description: The biggest tarantulas in the world, Goliath bird-eating spiders live in the deep rainforests of northern South America. Despite their intimidating name, they don't eat birds frequently.
fun_facts:
Even with eight eyes, the Goliath bird-eating tarantula doesn't see much. It uses the hairs on its legs and abdomen to sense vibrations on the ground or in the air.
	While their name has the term "bird-eating" in it, they don't eat birds frequently.
	The Goliath bird-eating tarantula makes noise by rubbing bristles on its legs together. This hissing noise, called stridulation, is loud enough to be heard up to 15 feet away.

label: Gray tree frog
description: Gray tree frogs are large, arboreal species common throughout much of the eastern U.S. and southeastern Canada. They have highly adapted toe tips for climbing and change color based on their temperature and activity.
fun_facts:
The gray tree frog's scientific name is Hyla versicolor, which comes from the Latin for "variable color." It is named for its ability to alter its skin color based on the time of day and surrounding temperature. The skin becomes much lighter at night and darker during the day.
	The gray tree frog hibernates in the winter by taking refuge in trees. It survives freezing temperatures by producing glycerol to "freeze" itself while maintaining interior metabolic processes at a very slow rate.

label: Banded leporinus
description: Banded leporinus are torpedo-shaped, striped yellow and black freshwater fish found primarily in the creeks and streams of the Amazon River basin in Brazil, Colombia and Venezuela where they feed on plants, fruits and leaves.
fun_facts: Banded leporinus have been observed jumping.

label: Pink-toed tarantula
description: The pink-toed tarantula is a small, arboreal species native to the rainforests of South America. It has a dark body with pink coloring at the tips of its legs.
fun_facts:
The name tarantula originated in the Renaissance period and referred to a small wolf spider from Taranto, Italy.
	 Pink-toed tarantulas can throw hairs from their body as a form of defense.

label: Plecostomus
description: The plecostomus, or suckermouth catfish, is found in fresh and brackish waters and prefers fast-flowing streams and rivers with pebbly substrate. Its coloring varies based on its surroundings and environment. These catfish are sometimes referred to as "janitor fish" for their ability to clean tank algae.
fun_facts:
Pelcostomus are sometimes referred to as "janitor fish" for their ability to clean tank algae.
	Males guard the eggs.

label: Titi monkey
description: White-eared titi monkeys, also called Bolivian titis or Bolivian gray titis, are vocal, social monkeys that live along rivers and beside lakes in the Amazon River Basin.
fun_facts:
Titi monkeys have been seen chewing leaves and then rubbing the pulp on their chest. The reason for this is unknown.
	Tail entwining—when two individuals sit with their tails wrapped around each other—is used to reinforce bonds amongst pairs. Tail twining is especially common between the adult male and female and takes place when two family members are sitting together. This is true whether the monkeys are awake or asleep.

label: Rock hyrax
description: Rock hyraxes, also called rock dassies or rock rabbits, are small, stub-tailed, rabbit-like animals native to Africa. Though rock hyraxes resemble rodents, their closest living relatives are actually elephants and manatees. These social mammals primarily eat vegetation.
fun_facts:
Their upper incisors grow continuously and look like small tusks.
	Despite looking like rodents, their closest relatives are actually elephants and manatees.
	Hyraxes consistently urinate in the same place, and the large amounts of calcium carbonate in their urine turns the cliffs where they live white. The calcium carbonate crystals were used as medicine, both by several African tribes as well as by Europeans, to treat such ailments as epilepsy, hysteria and various injuries.

label: Short-eared elephant shrew
description: Also called sengis, elephant shrews are more closely related to elephants than to true shrews. Their name comes from their long, flexible, highly sensitive snouts. Of the 17 living species of elephant shrews, the short-eared elephant shrew is the smallest.
fun_facts:
Short-eared elephant shrews clean themselves with dust baths.
	Their long tails are lined with knobbed bristles. The exact function of the bristles is unknown, but they may be used like swabs to spread their scent.

label: Striped skunk
description: Instantly recognizable, striped skunks are known for their signature coloration and for their ability to emit a strong and pungent odor when upset. They are native to the United States and Canada.
fun_facts: One of the most notable characteristics of this animal is its defense system; striped skunks have the ability to spray a foul smelling fluid from two glands located near the base of the tail. This oily musk, expelled through the anus, can cause temporary blindness and pain if sprayed in the eyes of a potential attacker. Juvenile skunks are capable of spraying at 8 days old, around two weeks before their eyes open.

label: Meerkat
description: Meerkats are active carnivores that live in burrows in Africa. Remarkably social, they live in groups that can number up to 30 individuals (called mobs) that cooperate in keeping watch over the mob and scare off predators or other meerkats.
fun_facts:
One member of the group will act as a sentinel, on the lookout for predators. The sentry will stand on its hind legs, often using its tail as support, or perch in a bush or tree, scanning for danger. Individuals rotate sentinel duty throughout the day.
	A group of meerkats is called a mob.

label: Red-rumped agouti
description: Similar in appearance to a Guinea pig—but larger and with longer legs—red-rumped agoutis are members of the rodent family. They are native to South America and are important members of their ecosystem, because they are the only mammals within their native range that are able to open the husk of a Brazil nut.
fun_facts: Red-rumped agoutis make a significant contribution to the forestation of their natural habitat; they are the only mammal species within their native range known to be able to open a Brazil nut husk.

label: Black-tailed prairie dog
description: There are five species of prairie dog: black-tailed, Utah, Mexican, white-tailed and Gunnison's. The Smithsonian's National Zoo exhibits black-tailed prairie dogs. Social rodents and industrious diggers, prairie dogs dig prairie dog towns which are U-shaped with chambers connected by "tunnels."
fun_facts:
Black-tailed prairie dogs are actually a species of ground squirrel, named "dog" because of their alarm bark.
	The largest prairie dog colony ever recorded spanned over 25,000 square miles (65,000 square kilometers) and was home to an estimated 400 million prairie dogs.

label: Burrowing owl
description: Burrowing owls are one of the smallest owl species. Unlike most owls, they are very active during the day and nest in underground burrows. They are native to the deserts, plains and fields of western North America, and the drier regions of Central and South America.
fun_facts:
Burrowing owls are the only small owl species to perch on the ground. Rather than fly away, they often run or flatten themselves against the ground when disturbed.
	While still in the nest, a burrowing owlet's distress cry mimics the sound of a rattlesnake, scaring away predators.

label: Damaraland mole rat
description: Larger and furrier than their more famous cousins the naked mole-rats, Damaraland mole rats also live in social, subterranean colonies. These omnivores range from western Zambia to northwestern South Africa.
fun_facts:
Damaraland mole rats dig with their protuberant lower incisors and forefeet. Their large lower incisors can move separately.
	Like naked mole-rats, Damaraland mole rats exhibit co-operative breeding, where some individuals forgo reproduction to help others breed. This type of reproduction is most common among insects like honeybees.

label: Degu
description: These small, social rodents are native to the slopes of the Andes, where they form groups of up to ten.
fun_facts:
If a predator grabs a degu by the tail, a ring of thin skin at the tail's base will tear off, allowing the degu to escape. There is very little blood loss and the wound heals quickly, although the tail will not grow back.
	Degus sand bathe by marking an area of sand with urine and rolling around in it.

label: Geoffroy's marmoset
description: Marmosets and tamarins are small, squirrel-like monkeys that have many features that are unusual among primates. Marmosets are arboreal with claws that help them to cling to tree trunks. Geoffroy's marmosets are omnivores native to the lowland rainforests of Brazil.
fun_facts:
Tamarins and marmosets are the among the only monkeys or apes that regularly give birth to twins.
	Scientists suggest that marmosets have evolved to take advantage of an insect diet, and as a part of the process have become smaller.

label: Red ruffed lemur
description: A small primate species native only to Madagascar, red ruffed lemurs live in just one protected area and are critically endangered.
fun_facts:
Red ruffed lemurs (and lemurs in general) have a tooth comb and a grooming claw that is used for grooming fur.
	Even though they don't encounter venomous snakes in the wild, red ruffed lemurs at the Duke Primate Center developed a venomous snake call in the presence of copperheads. They can also understand the alarm calls of black-and-white ruffed lemurs, which live in a different part of Madagascar.

label: Przewalski's horse
description: Przewalski's horses, critically endangered horses found in Mongolia, are the last truly wild horse. Once thought to be the ancestor to the domestic horse, they are actually distant cousins. Mitochondrial DNA suggests that they diverged from a common ancestor 500,000 years ago.
fun_facts:
Przewalski's horses have 66 chromosomes, compared to the 64 that domestic horses have. It is unusual in that they can produce fertile hybrids with the domestic horse (65 chromosomes) that are able to breed and produce offspring. The hybrids look like Przewalski's horses, and the only way to identify them is through chromosome testing.
	Przewalski's horses are called "takhi," which means "spirit" in Mongolia.

label: Whooping crane
description: Whooping cranes, named for their impressively loud call, are native to North America. Once faced with extinction, they are now recovering with the help of conservation science efforts, including significant efforts by Smithsonian scientists. In 2018, the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute opened a new breeding facility. The chicks that hatch there will be candidates for reintroduction to the wild.
fun_facts:
A whooping crane's trachea coils about 9 inches (23 centimeters) into their sternum while calling, which allows for increased volume and variation in pitch.
	While whooping crane hatchlings cannot fly, they can swim to escape predators.
	Operation Migration, a program assigned with the task of helping cranes learn migratory paths, helps conserve whooping cranes by leading migrations with an ultralight aircraft.

label: Golden lion tamarin
description: A striking species, golden lion tamarins are small social South America primates with a magnificent reddish-gold coat and a long, backswept mane. Once down to 200 individuals in the wild, intensive conservation efforts have helped the population recover. Still an endangered species, there are about 2,500 in the wild — about a third of which are descendants of golden lion tamarins raised in human care.
fun_facts:
Golden lion tamarins move quadrupedally through the trees and can spring and leap between branches and vines.
	In the early 1970s, there were as few as 200 golden lion tamarins in the wild. They were upgraded from critically endangered to endangered in 2003 following intensive conservation efforts. About one-third of the wild population today originated from golden lion tamarins raised in human care.

label: Sand cat
description: Sand cats are a small, solitary cat native to deserts in Africa and Asia. Superbly adapted to life in the desert, they can live without water, run on shifting sand and detect prey underground.
fun_facts:
Sand cats have dense hair and pads on the soles of each foot that protect against the intense heat and cold of their habitat, as well as aiding in movement across the sand. The pads help them navigate across shifting sands.
	Sand cats are fearless snake hunters—their prey can include venomous vipers and other snakes.

label: Banded mongoose
description: Banded mongooses are small, catlike carnivores native to Africa. They are famous for their ability to kill snakes and are one of the most social mongoose species, living in packs of up to 20.
fun_facts:
When a predator approaches banded mongooses, they bunch together and move as a group, creating the appearance of a single large animal. The individuals in front may even stand on their hind legs and make snapping lunges toward the predator.
	The more social mongoose species tend to be smaller than the solitary species.

label: Brush-tailed bettong
description: Brush-tailed bettongs, also called brush-tailed rat kangaroos and woylies, are small, critically endangered, bipedal marsupials native to Australia. They possess prehensile tails and are prodigious diggers.
fun_facts:
Brush-tailed bettongs rarely, if ever, drink water or eat green plant matter.
	Brush-tailed bettongs' tails are prehensile, which allows for collection of materials for nesting.
	Individual brush-tailed bettongs dig 38 to 115 investigatory holes each night, which equates to each individual moving about 6 tons of soil each year.

label: Black howler monkey
description: These South American monkeys are the loudest terrestrial animal in the Western Hemisphere, and are usually the largest and most abundant primate wherever they live. Blond at birth, males turn black as they mature, while females stay blonde their entire lives.
fun_facts:
Howlers make up the highest percentage of the primates in the areas that they occupy.
	Black howler monkeys are one of the few primate species with different coat colors in males and females. Males have a black coat, while females are blonde.

label: Black-footed ferret
description: Black-footed ferrets are North America's only native ferret species. They once ranged across the western plains but were thought to be extinct until a small population was discovered in 1981. Thanks to breeding and reintroduction programs, including the work of the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute, black-footed ferrets have made an incredible recovery!
fun_facts:
Black-footed ferrets are very playful, especially as juveniles. Young at play will wrestle, arch their backs and hop backward with their mouths wide open, in a display known as the "ferret dance."
	Once thought extinct, an isolated population of black-footed ferrets was discovered. Eighteen wild animals were caught to establish a breeding colony, from which all wild black-footed ferrets are now descended.
	Black-footed ferrets are North America's only native ferret species

label: Dwarf mongoose
description: True to its name, the dwarf mongoose is the smallest mongoose. In fact, it is the smallest African carnivore. It is an extremely social and territorial animal, living in packs with as many as 32 mongooses.
fun_facts:
Dwarf mongooses will forage with hornbills. Hornbills catch insects, rodents and other prey flushed by the pack and in return serve as lookouts, sounding alarm calls when avian predators are sighted.
	Hornbills will gather at termite mounds where their mongoose packs spend the night and wait for them to emerge, sometimes even providing wake up calls. If hornbills fail to appear, mongooses hesitate to leave their refuge and begin foraging.

label: Fennec fox
description: The smallest of all canids, fennec foxes sport extraordinarily large ears that help them hunt at night. They are native to Africa and Arabia where they live in deserts and arid regions.
fun_facts:
Extreme panting helps fennec foxes keep their temperatures regulated when the heat climbs; breathing rates climb from 23 breaths per minute to up to 690.
	Despite their diminutive stature, fennec foxes are surprisingly good at jumping. Adults can jump up to 3 feet (1 meter) when standing.

label: Greater Madagascar hedgehog tenrec
description: Greater Madagascar tenrecs are spiky, nocturnal, insect-eating small mammals. Though sometimes confused with hedgehogs, tenrecs are actually members of a different order. They come in a wide range of shapes and sizes, and they live only in Madagascar where they were one of the first mammals to colonize.
fun_facts:
When threatened, greater Madagascar tenrecs can roll up completely in a ball, tucking their head and limbs toward their belly.
	When they're alarmed, tenrecs produce a pusling keen. This sound is barely audible, and is delivered as a chain of pulses at a rate of eight per second.

label: Lesser Madagascar hedgehog tenrec
description: Lesser Madagascar tenrecs, also called lesser hedgehog tenrecs, are small, nocturnal animals covered in spines. Though sometimes confused with hedgehogs, lesser tenrecs are actually members of a different order. Lesser tenrecs have poor eyesight, but their whiskers are very sensitive and their senses of smell and hearing are well developed.
fun_facts:
Tenrecs retain characteristics that were perhaps more widespread in early placental mammals, including a low and variable body temperature.
	Many people confuse lesser tenrecs with a species of African hedgehog found in pet stores but these are not the same animals; hedgehogs are members of a different order.

label: Golden-headed lion tamarin
description: Named for their thick, long, golden manes, golden-headed lion tamarins live only in Brazil. Like many tamarin species, they are tree-dwelling, fruit-eating primates. Golden-headed lion tamarins are an endangered species.
fun_facts:
Golden-headed lion tamarins move quadrupedally through the main canopy of the forest. When climbing down tree trunks, they can move with their heads or tails downward.
	Tamarins play a significant role in seed dispersal; many of the fruits they eat have seeds that pass through the monkey's digestive tract unharmed and end up deposited well away from the parent plant.

label: La Plata three-banded armadillo
description: La Plata three-banded armadillos, also known as southern three-banded armadillos, are the only armadillo that can curl up into a complete ball. Native to South America, they are also one of the only armadillos that are not good diggers.
fun_facts:
La Plata three-banded armadillos are the only armadillo to rely heavily on their armor. Some other armadillo species cannot roll up because they have too many plates to curl.
	They do not dig burrows like most armadillos, but use the abandoned burrows of anteaters when they can get them.

label: Roseate spoonbill
description: Roseate spoonbills are bright pink birds with long, spoon-shaped bills. They populate marsh areas in Florida and the Gulf Coast where their populations are recovering from decades of over-hunting.
fun_facts:
Spoonbills fly in long diagonal lines with their necks and legs completely stretched out.
	It is thought that the roseate spoonbill receives its bright coloring from the pigments of the crustaceans that it eats.
	When it walks, the roseate spoonbill swings its head back and forth in a sideways motion.

label: African clawed frog
description: African clawed frogs are native to eastern and southern Africa and parts of western Africa. They have been used extensively used for research, and are considered an invasive species on four continents, due to their release into the wild from research laboratories. African clawed frogs prefer to spend all of their time in stagnant water where they live, feed and reproduce.
fun_facts:
At times, when its pond dries up, the African clawed frog can burrow in the mud and may lay dormant for up to a year.
	The African clawed frog was the first vertebrate cloned in a laboratory.
	Their skin produces a type of antibiotic that heals wounds rapidly, presumably a useful adaptation in the stagnant, microbe-filled waters where they live.

label: Aquatic caecilian
description: Aquatic caecilians, also known as rubber eels, are found in Colombian and Venezuelan lowland rivers and streams. Looking more like large worms than the legless amphibians they are, they can grow up to 22 inches in length and have slimy smooth dark gray skin.
fun_facts:
Like all amphibians, caecilians breathe primarily through their skin but will occasionally come to the surface to breathe air through their lungs.
	Aquatic caecilians have a sensory organ in the form of a tentacle that lies on the upper jaw behind the nostril and carries chemical messages.

label: Arapaima
description: The arapaima is a massive yet sleek, streamlined freshwater fish native to the streams of the Amazon River basin. It can breathe air, allowing it to survive in pools with low water levels or decaying vegetation.
fun_facts:
The arapaima's mouth works like a vacuum. When hungry, it opens its mouth to suck up nearby food.
	This fish can breathe air and stay submerged for 10-20 minutes at a time. It can survive up to 24 hours outside of the water!

label: Barred tiger salamander
description: Barred tiger salamanders are one of the longest terrestrial salamanders in North America. They are primarily nocturnal and live in a variety of habitats, including forests, fields, meadows, grasslands and deserts.
fun_facts: Barred tiger salamanders are one of the longest terrestrial salamanders in North America, and possibly in the world.

label: Black pacu
description: The black pacu is a large, nonaggressive, fruit-eating species of fish found in the upper Amazon River basin.
fun_facts:
The pacu is a fruit-eating relative of the piranha and is often mistaken as one in the pet trade.
	The pacu's body is darker below and lighter above. This is unusual in aquatic animals which usually exhibit the opposite, as it helps with camouflage.

label: Brazilian rainbow boa
description: The Brazilian rainbow boa is a medium-sized terrestrial boa native to the Amazon River basin. It is named for its iridescent skin which refracts light and creates a rainbow-colored effect.
fun_facts:
The Brazilian rainbow boa is named for its iridescent skin that refracts light and creates a rainbow-colored effect.
	Sexual maturity in Brazilian rainbow boas is determined by length rather than age. Males may breed at 4 feet and females at 4.5 feet in length.

label: Chilean rose tarantula
description: Chilean rose tarantulas are calm, docile spiders native to desert scrub habitats in South America. They have dark bodies with rose-hued hair. These active predators use their body size to subdue prey.
fun_facts:
The name "tarantula" originated in the Renaissance period to refer to a small wolf spider from Taranto, Italy.
	They are considered very calm and docile and, as a result, are one of the most popular and widespread tarantula species in the pet trade.

label: Eastern newt
description: Eastern newts are native to the U.S. They have yellow or green-brown skin with red dots that signal their slight toxicity. The eastern newt's appearance evolves throughout its three distinct life stages: larvae, juvenile (or eft) and adult. Its primary habitat shifts between water and land, depending on its life stage.
fun_facts:
Eastern newts consume aquatic insects, such as mosquitos. This is beneficial to humans, because eastern newts may help to control insect populations.
	Eastern newts' skin is slightly toxic, which helps protect it from predators.

label: Flagtail characin
description: Flatail characins, also called kissing prochilodus, have silver bodies and colorful fins. They live in the Amazonia River system.
fun_facts: Flagtail characins migrate upriver to spawn.

label: Fowler's toad
description: Fowler's toads are small and brown, gray or olive in color. They are nocturnal and range throughout the temperate parts of the eastern U.S. and parts of southeastern Canada.
fun_facts: Female Fowler's toads lay eggs in strings with clutches of up to 20,000 eggs.

label: Asian elephant
description: The largest living land mammals, elephants are intelligent, social and vital to their ecosystems. Slightly smaller than their African cousins, Asian elephants are native to India and Southeast Asia. Much of what scientists know about wild elephant behavior comes from African bush elephant studies. Research on wild endangered Asian elephants is difficult and sparse, and zoo elephants are valuable sources of knowledge. Online visitors can catch a glimpse of the Smithsonian's National Zoo's elephants on the Elephant Cam.
fun_facts:
Not all elephants develop visible tusks. In Asian elephants, only some males have large, prominent tusks. Most female and some male Asian elephants have small tusks, called tushes, which seldom protrude more than an inch or two from the lip line.
	Elephants communicate over long distances using low-pitched sounds that are barely audible to humans. These powerful infrasonic rumbles contain specific messages that can be heard and understood by other elephants more than 2 miles away.

label: Von der Decken's hornbill
description: Von der Decken hornbills are native to dry regions of eastern Africa. Males have large, red bills while females have black bills. Like other hornbills, female Von der Decken hornbills bury themselves alive to hatch and rear their chicks. For two months, the male feeds the female and the chicks through a slit in the mud nest.
fun_facts: Von der Decken hornbills are named a German explorer, Baron Karl Klaus von der Decken, who wrote about the species while exploring in Africa.

label: Larger Malay mouse-deer
description: Larger Malay mouse-deer, also called chevrotains, are one of the smallest living hoofed mammals. These nocturnal ungulates are typically found in south and southeast Asia.
fun_facts:
Larger Malay mouse-deer are known as "living fossils" because they have changed little in 30 million years.
	When standing on all fours, their hindquarters are taller than their front end.

label: Long-tailed chinchilla
description: The endangered, long-tailed chinchilla is a medium-sized rodent with famously thick, beautiful fur. It is a social, matriarchal animal native to the Andes mountain range.
fun_facts:
Chinchillas' teeth are dark orange.
	Their fur is so dense that up to 60 hairs can grow out of one follicle.

label: Malagasy giant jumping rat
description: The endangered Malagasy giant jumping rat is a large cousin of the rat family native only to Madagascar. True to its name, it can leap nearly 40 inches (100 centimeters) into the air.
fun_facts:
Malagasy giant jumping rats are the largest rodent native to Madagascar; they are found nowhere else on Earth.
	This is the only living species of its genus.
	They can jump nearly 40 inches into the air when threatened.

label: Naked mole-rat
description:
Naked mole-rats, as their name suggests, are pink, nearly hairless subterranean rodents. These surprisingly long-lived animals are one of the only true eusocial mammals and live in underground burrows in eastern Africa. 

WATCH LIVE: The new and improved Naked Mole-rat Cam is here! Don't forget to stop by the new naked mole-rat exhibit on your next visit to the Smithsonian's National Zoo.
fun_facts:
Naked mole-rats are not completely hairless. They have sensory whiskers on their faces and on their tails, and they have hairs between their toes that allow their feet to function as brooms with which they sweep soil.
	Unlike most other mammals, they cannot maintain a steady body temperature. They keep warm by huddling together and by basking in warmer shallow tunnels.
	Naked mole-rats are the longest-living rodents in the world! In fact, the Zoo has two distinct habitats: one habitat is for geriatric mole-rats approaching 30 years old, and one multistory habitat is for younger mole-rats.

label: Northern tree shrew
description: Tree shrews look remarkably similar to squirrels. They are native to Southeast Asia and are the only members of their taxonomic order.
fun_facts:
Tree shrews were once placed in the order formerly known as Insectivora, and then classified as primates for 50 years. Recent research distinguishes them from both orders and they are now classified in the order Scandentia, the only family in that order.
	Tree shrews have a symbiotic relationship with pitcher plants, a group of plants with large, tube-shaped flowers.

label: Pale-headed saki monkey
description: These small New World monkeys live almost completely in trees, seldom if ever coming down to the ground. They are native to northern South America.
fun_facts: Pale-headed saki monkeys have been known to cover 33 feet (10 meters) in a single bound when escaping from danger.

label: Prehensile-tailed porcupine
description: Prehensile-tailed porcupines, also called coendous, are one of 12 species of New World porcupines. They are native to South America, where they live in trees and eat fruits.
fun_facts:
These porcupines use their prehensile tail to grasp! Half of the weight of the tail is composed of muscle.
	It could take up to six months to determine a prehensile-tailed porcupine's sex, because its sexual organs are internal. Instead, Zoo scientists use the innovative technique of analyzing DNA extracted from a quill to rapidly determine the sex.

label: Prevost's squirrel
description: Prevost's squirrels are tree squirrels found in Southeast Asia. Their fur has three distinct bands of color: jet black, white and reddish-brown.
fun_facts:
At night, Prevost's squirrels rest in hollows in trees or on tree branches in nests built of leaves and twigs. They wrap their tails around them at night for warmth.
	Unlike ground squirrels, tree squirrels do not hibernate.

label: Rock cavy
description: Rock cavies are similar to their relatives, domestic guinea pigs. They are solitary animals that live in rocky landscapes in northeastern Brazil, and are surprisingly accomplished climbers.
fun_facts:
Rock cavies have heavily padded feet and blunt nails, rather than the well-developed sharp nails found in other genera in this family. These adaptations help them move on slick rock surfaces.
	They are surprisingly agile climbers; they do most of their foraging in trees and can leap from boulder to boulder.

label: Screaming hairy armadillo
description: True to their name, screaming hairy armadillos are a hirsute armadillo species that emit a loud squeal when threatened. They are native to the Monte Desert in South America.
fun_facts:
Screaming hairy armadillos consume large amounts of sand while foraging for food; accounts of 50 percent of an armadillo's stomach contents being filled with sand have been recorded.
	Screaming hairy armadillos do not need to drink water regularly; efficient kidneys and the ability to retain moisture in the plants that they consume allow them to go long periods without drinking.

label: Southern tamandua
description: Tamanduas are arboreal relatives of anteaters, whom they resemble. Native to South America, they can live in a variety of habitats and eat mainly social insects such as ants, termites and bees.
fun_facts:
Tamanduas, and all anteaters, belong to the suborder Vermilingua, which literally means "worm-tongue," describing their famous long tongues.
	The underside of their tails is fur-less; this allows them to grip tree branches more securely as they move through the trees.

label: Bobcat
description: Bobcats are often confused with the other three "lynx" species, the Canadian lynx, Iberian lynx and Eurasian lynx. Bobcats are slightly smaller and live in warmer, temperate habitats. They are excellent climbers and fast sprinters.
fun_facts:
Bobcats are often confused with the other three lynx species. Bobcats live in warmer climates, while other lynx occupy cold, northern latitudes and are adapted to living through long winters and deep snow.
	Bobcats can run at up to 30 miles per hour. They place their back feet in the same spots where their front feet have stepped to reduce noise when hunting.

label: Caracal lynx
description: With ruddy coats and tufted ears, caracals are incredibly striking animals. They are also the heaviest of the small African cats. These agile hunters range along the African continent, up into the Arabian Peninsula through northwest India.
fun_facts:
Caracals are the fastest felids of their size! They are also excellent jumpers and climbers.
	They are supremely acrobatic and can leap agilely into the air to bring down prey, such as guinea fowl, on the wing.

label: North American porcupine
description: Instantly recognizable from its shape and coating of 30,000 quills, porcupines are native to the forests of North America. While they can't shoot their quills at predators, the quills are loosely attached and designed to deter predators.
fun_facts:
Porcupines are covered in about 30,000 quills. They cannot throw or shoot their quills. Because quills are so lightly attached, they come off easily when a predator encounters them.
	While porcupines spend most of the time on the ground, they are good climbers and regularly climb trees in search of food and occasionally even build nests in trees. They are also good swimmers.

label: Giant anteater
description: Giant anteaters are the largest of the four anteater species, reaching lengths of 6-8 feet. They are native to Central and South America, where they feed on tiny termites and ants using their 2-foot-long tongue, which can flick in and out up to 150 times per minute.
fun_facts:
A giant anteater's tongue is 2 feet long and can flick in and out of its mouth 150 times per minute.
	It's coated in sticky saliva, which allows anteaters to slurp up ants and termites.
	Research has found that giant anteaters can identify a particular species of ant or termite by smell before they rip apart a nest.

label: Lion
description: The world's most social felines, lions roam the savannas and grasslands of the African continent, hunting cooperatively and raising cubs in prides. Online visitors can catch a glimpse of the Smithsonian's National Zoo's lions on the Lion Cam.
fun_facts:
Female lions raise the cubs and are also the primary hunters.
	Without their coats, lion and tiger bodies are so similar that only experts can tell them apart.

label: Tiger
description:
Among the largest species of cats in the world, tigers are powerful hunters with sharp teeth, strong jaws and agile bodies. They range across Asia from Russia all the way to Sumatra and mainland Southeast Asia. Researchers still have much to learn about these beautiful, endangered cats. 

There is currently one recognized species of tiger, Panthera tigris. Scientists have further classified the tiger into nine subspecies: the extinct Bali, Caspian and Javan subspecies, and the living Malayan, Sumatran, South China, Indochinese, Bengal and Amur (or Siberian) subspecies. Of these six subspecies, AZA-accredited zoos currently manage three: Amur, Malayan and Sumatran. The Smithsonian's National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute is home to Sumatran and Amur tigers; Sumatran tigers are listed as Critically Endangered on the International Union for Conservation of Nature's Red List, and Amur tigers have been classified as Endangered.
fun_facts:
Sumatran tigers are the smallest of the tiger subspecies.
	Like a human fingerprint, no two tigers have the same pattern of stripes on their coats. Scientists can use these distinctions to identify tigers in the wild.
	Tigers are adept swimmers. They often go into the water to escape flies or cool off, and can easily cross rivers and lakes 5 miles (8 km) wide.

label: Japanese koi
description: Koi fish are colorful, ornamental versions of the common carp. Modern Japanese koi are believed to date back to early 19th-century Japan where wild, colorful carp were caught, kept and bred by rice farmers. The word “koi” comes from the Japanese word for “carp.”
fun_facts:
A common misconception is that koi are large goldfish; although koi and goldfish are both domesticated from carp, they are distinct species.
	While carp are popular with anglers, koi are bred for ornamental ponds. Koi and goldfish are the most popular freshwater, ornamental fish throughout the world. 
	The koi breeding industry can be quite lucrative, with rumors of individual show-quality koi selling for hundreds of thousands of dollars.

label: Channel catfish
description: Bottom-dwelling, opportunistic omnivores, channel catfish live in freshwater rivers, lakes, streams and ponds throughout North America.
fun_facts:
Catfish have taste receptors all over their bodies.
	The world record weight for a channel catfish was a 58-pound (26.3 kilograms) fish caught in South Carolina in 1964.

label: Chicken
description: Domestic chickens have small heads, short beaks and wings, and a round body perched on featherless legs. They are a subspecies of red junglefowl, a species native to southern Asia. Many different breeds exist within this subspecies, and the Smithsonian's National Zoo exhibits a hybrid, leghorn/salmon faverolle, that is hardy, extremely active and very noisy. This hybrid is also a prolific egg layer.
fun_facts:
Domestic chickens are a subspecies of red junglefowl (Gallus gallus), a species native to southern Asia.
	There are more chickens on Earth than any other bird species.

label: Miniature donkey
description: Intelligent, social, hardy animals, donkeys have been domesticated for their milk, strength and companionship for more than 6,000 years.
fun_facts:
The term "donkey" comes from dun (the usual grayish-brown color) and the suffix "ky" meaning small. Male donkeys are called "jacks," and females are "jennets."
	The donkey was first domesticated about six thousand years ago.

label: Ossabaw Island hog
description: Domesticated Spanish pigs escaped on Ossabaw Island where they went feral and became their own subspecies — smaller than typical pigs and with a unique metabolism.
fun_facts:
Ossabow Island hogs had to adapt to the food cycle on the island, which provides little to eat during the spring season. They developed a unique biochemical system of fat metabolism, enabling them to store a larger proportion of fat than any other hog.
	These hogs naturally have a form of low-grade, non-insulin-dependent diabetes, making them excellent medical research animals.

label: Emperor newt
description: The highly toxic emperor newt (also called the Mandarin or Yunnan newt) lives only in the mountains along a handful of rivers in western China. These newts face threats from over-harvesting and habitat destruction.
fun_facts: The species name comes from the Mandarin words "shan" (mountain) and "jing" (spirit or demon).

label: Golden mantella frog
description: This small, beautiful, critically endangered frog lives only in a tiny, remote area of Madagascar. Two subspecies exist, both of which live at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo.
fun_facts:
Golden mantella frogs have evolved to be very similar in appearance and behavior to the poison frogs of South America (family Dendrobatidae).
	Golden mantella frogs live in groups usually consisting of twice as many males as females

label: Lemur leaf frog
description: Lemur leaf frogs, also called lemur tree frogs, are small, critically endangered frogs native to Central America.
fun_facts:
Lemur leaf frogs are able to change color at night when they are typically active.
	These amphibians are territorial. Males call with a short “tick” to warn other males they are nearby.

label: Lemur leaf frog
description: Lemur leaf frogs, also called lemur tree frogs, are small, critically endangered frogs native to Central America.
fun_facts:
Lemur leaf frogs are able to change color at night when they are typically active.
	These amphibians are territorial. Males call with a short “tick” to warn other males they are nearby.

label: Philippine crocodile
description: The small, critically endangered Philippine crocodile was once prevalent throughout the Philippines but now lives only on a few islands.
fun_facts:
Female Philippine crocodiles build the nest that houses their eggs, but both males and females guard it.
	The Philippine crocodile is one of the most endangered crocodilian species, with estimates of wild populations fewer than 100.

label: Radiated tortoise
description: The critically endangered radiated tortoise lives in the forests and scrublands of Madagascar. It has a smooth, high-domed carapace (or shell) marked with yellow lines that radiate from the center of each dark plate. Its body is yellow, with a black patch on its head.
fun_facts: The radiated tortoise's shell has blood vessels and nerves so, like other tortoises, it can feel when it is being touched.

label: Spider tortoise
description: The critically endangered spider tortoise lives only in Madagascar, where it is the smallest of four native tortoise species. It is named for the web-like pattern of yellow lines on its dark brown or black carapace.
fun_facts:
The spider tortoise, named for the yellow, web-like pattern of its shell, is the smallest of four tortoises that live only on the island of Madagascar.
	During the hot, dry season, these turtles aestivate, or go through a period of dormancy similar to hibernation.

label: Timor python
description: Timor pythons are large, extremely active snakes native to the southeastern islands of Indonesia though, interestingly, not the island of Timor.
fun_facts:
Despite their name, these pythons do not live on the island of Timor. They are found on the neighboring Lesser Sunda Islands.
	Timor pythons are considered one of the most nervous and high-strung pythons.

label: Tokay gecko
description: Tokay geckos are one of the largest living gecko species. They are found in south and southeast Asia, where they often live in the same areas as humans and eliminate unwanted insect pests. <!-- These lizards perform the same service in the Small Mammal House where they freely range. -->
fun_facts:
These geckos thrive in manmade environments, so they are sometimes utilized to control insects.
	They have the remains of a rudimentary third eye on the top of their head, which scientists believe helps regulate their activity in different light conditions.
	Their ears are visible as small holes on both sides of the head, and you can actually see straight through their heads through their ears.

label: Coronated tree frog
description: Also known as spiny-headed tree frogs, coronated tree frogs sport sharp, pointed projections on their head that give them their name. These rarely seen frogs live in the trees in subtropical forests and occasionally on coffee plantations.
fun_facts:
The coronated tree frog is the only species in this genus. Unlike many other tree frogs in the Hylidae family they lack finger webs.
	As tadpoles, they eat unfertilized eggs laid for them by the female. This is unusual for large tree frog species, but is also seen in several species of Dendrobates, as well as in the Jamaican laughing frog which is also in the family Hylidae.

label: White's tree frog
description: White's tree frogs are an adaptable species native to Australia and New Guinea. A milky white coating called "caerviein" helps them survive in dry areas, allowing them to live in agricultural and suburban areas.
fun_facts:
The species name caerulea means blue in Latin. This is interesting because they are not usually seen as blue, but as bright green.
	Extracts from the skin have medical uses such as fighting staphylococcus bacteria that can cause abscesses, lowering blood pressure and treating cold sores caused by the herpes virus.

label: Vietnamese mossy frog
description: The combination of the Vietnamese mossy frog's green body, black spots, tubercles and spines makes it look like a clump of moss, which it spends a large portion of its time pretending to be. Native to Vietnam, these frogs live in mossy caves and in the banks of rocky mountain streams.
fun_facts:
Vietnamese mossy frogs will fold into a ball when frightened and play dead. Their predators include tree-dwelling mammals and snakes.
	There are 11 species of Theloderma, all found in Southeast Asia. They all have bumpy skin and some sort of cryptic coloration. Other members of this group are brown and look like bark, and another species, the warty tree frog, looks like bird poop.

label: Smooth-sided toad
description: True to its name, the smooth-sided toad is one of the few toads with smooth skin. It lives in the tropical forests of northern South America, where it eats insects and small mammals.
fun_facts:
The warts behind smooth-sided toads' eyes are called parotid glands. The parotid glands produce toxins that interfere with a predator's heart function and can cause death due to heart failure.
	Smooth-sided toads breed in permanent and temporary water bodies, some of which the adult toads dig themselves.

label: Oriental fire-bellied toad
description: Fire-bellied toads, also called bombina, are warty, aquatic toads with bright orange or red undersides. These gregarious frogs are native to China and Russia.
fun_facts:
This family of toads cannot extend their tongues like other toads or frogs. To feed, they must leap forward and catch prey with their mouths.
	Their skin secretes a milky substance that irritates the mouth and eyes of attackers. A taste of the toxin usually deters predators from ever attaching again. However, grass snakes and other water serpents have been known to attack and devour these toads without ill effects.

label: Abyssinian ground hornbill
description: Abyssinian ground hornbills are large, primarily terrestrial birds that live in savannas, grasslands, and scrub across north-central Africa from Senegal and Guinea on the western coast to Ethiopia on the eastern coast. They have to have a tree in their habitat to nest.
fun_facts:
The noticeable "eyelashes" of Abyssinian ground hornbills are actually modified feathers that protect their eyes from injury.
	While they are able to fly, Abyssinian ground hornbills prefer to run if threatened. They will, however, fly to catch prey or defend territory.

label: Alpaca
description: The alpaca is a small relative of the camel and was domesticated by Andean people for its wool. It has a slender body, a small head and big, pointed ears. Its body is covered in soft fleece, and its feet are soft and padded. It is believed that alpacas were developed through selective breeding, heavily influenced by the vicuna, more than 6,000 years ago.
fun_facts:
It is believed that more than 6,000 years ago, alpacas were developed through selective breeding heavily influenced by the wild vicuna.
	Alpacas were fully domesticated by Andean people centuries before the Incas as a source of fuel, meat and fiber for fabric.

label: Cow
description: Cattle are important domesticated animals that provide meat and milk. Many breeds exist, some emphasizing beef production, others emphasizing dairy production. The Smithsonian's National Zoo exhibits a polled Hereford, which is a beef breed. Cattle are members of the Bovidae family, which also includes gazelles, African antelope, Asian water buffalo, bison and domesticated species, such as sheep and goats.
fun_facts:
Cattle have panoramic vision, but their depth perception is only focused in a small forward view.
	The word cattle comes from the Old French word chattle, which means "possession."

label: Black-crowned night heron
description: Though wild birds, black-crowned night herons are a common sight at the Smithsonian's National Zoo in the summer, where they have a breeding colony. This is their only rookery in Washington, D.C.
fun_facts:
The young can be aggressive — regurgitating or defecating on human intruders.
	Black-crowned night herons have been hunted for food, though they are hunted for this purpose much less frequently now. If they nest near human settlements, they are considered pests.

label: Blue-billed curassow
description: A critically endangered forest bird, the blue-billed curassow's range has shrunk to include only a few small forest remnants in Colombia.
fun_facts:
Primarily terrestrial birds, blue-billed curassows stick to the forest floor to eat.
	Only the female curassow has a knob on her bill.

label: Common peafowl
description: Male peafowl, also called peacocks, are instantly recognizable with their striking tail feathers. Revered in their original range country of India, peafowl have spread around the world as symbols of wealth and power. They are the largest member of the pheasant family.
fun_facts:
Peafowl tend to walk or run rather than fly. They prefer to fly only in strong, short bursts to escape predators or to reach the tree tops in which they roost at night.
	In Indian folklore, peafowl are believed to be important snake killers, able to hypnotize them and spoil the snakes' eggs.

label: Emu
description: Emus are large, flightless birds resembling and related to ostriches. They are native to Australia.
fun_facts:
The emu is a fast runner and can reach speeds of up to 31 mph (50 km/hr). Their long legs enable them to walk considerable distances or outrun danger. Emus are also strong swimmers.
	In emus, as in most ratites—large flightless birds—the male incubates the eggs.

label: Greater rhea
description: The largest South American bird, rheas are flightless and resemble ostriches.
fun_facts:
Rheas have unusually long wings for flightless birds. They use their wings like an airplane rudder balance while running and to dodge predators.
	Rhea feathers are used to make feather dusters in South America.
	The male rhea incubates the eggs and cares for the chicks after they hatch.

label: Green-winged macaw
description: This brightly colored relative of the parrot is native to north and central South America.
fun_facts: Macaws ingest mineralized sand and clay, which helps neutralize the toxins in the seeds and nuts they eat.

label: King vulture
description: King vultures are one of the largest New World vulture, second only to condors. They range from Mexico to Argentina and feed on carrion.
fun_facts:
The king vulture spends hours soaring without flapping its wings. It flies much higher in the air than other species of vulture, which prefer to soar close to the treetops.
	When a king vulture lands, other birds make way for it. Though it appears to dominate over a feeding site, this vulture actually relies on other, stronger-beaked carrion-eaters to initially rip open the hide of a carcass.

label: Kori bustard
description: Kori bustards are the world's heaviest flying birds. They live in grasslands and savannas in eastern and southern Africa.
fun_facts:
The kori bustard is one of the world's heaviest flying birds, however, it lives on the ground and is reluctant to fly unless in serious danger.
	Kori bustards are one of the few species of birds that drink water using a sucking motion rather than scooping.

label: North Island brown kiwi
description: Kiwi are flightless, nocturnal birds native only to New Zealand. They have the second largest egg per body weight of any bird.
fun_facts:
The kiwi has the second largest egg for body size of any bird—an average of 15 percent of its body weight, compared to only 2 percent in the ostrich.
	The kiwi is so remarkably unbirdlike in appearance and behavior that is has sometimes been referred to as an honorary "mammal."
	The brown kiwi is the only bird known in which both the left and the right ovaries consistently occur—most birds have only one.

label: Southern swamp sparrow
description: The southern swamp sparrow is a small songbird native to North America, where it breeds in the wetlands of the northern U.S. and Canada. They spend their winters along the Gulf of Mexico.
fun_facts:
Southern swamp sparrows often conceal their nests made of fine grasses between cattails or among other vegetation.
	They lay three to six greenish-white eggs with spotty brown marks and lay two clutches of eggs each year.

label: Barred owl
description: Barred owls are one of North America's most common and most vocal owls. These large predators are willing to eat anything they can hunt and kill. They have brownish-gray feathers and brown eyes, unlike most owls which have yellow eyes.
fun_facts:
Barred owls that prey heavily on crayfish can develop pink-tinged breast feathers.
	They are expanding their range into the Pacific Northwest and have begun to hybridize with their smaller, critically endangered cousin, the spotted owl.

label: American flamingo
description: American flamingos are one of the largest species of flamingo. Found in the Caribbean and along the northern coast of South America, these extraordinarily social birds live in flocks that sometimes number in the thousands. A pigment in their food gives their feathers their flamboyant pink color.
fun_facts:
The flamingo's pink or red color comes from its food, including algae and shrimp.
	Flamingos often stand on one leg, with their head resting on their body and their other leg tucked under the abdomen. This posture cuts heat loss through the legs and feet.

label: Maned wolf
description: The largest canid in South America, the maned wolf looks like a fox, is called a wolf, and is closely related to neither. Maned wolves primarily eat small animals, fruits and vegetables.
fun_facts:
Maned wolf urine has a powerful aroma, reminding many humans of the way skunks smell.
	The maned wolf is the largest canid of South America. It looks more like a long-legged fox than a wolf. Genetic studies show that it is neither fox nor true wolf, but a distinct species. It is the only member of its genus, Chrysocyon.

label: Blue crane
description: The blue crane, also known as the paradise or Stanley crane, is the national bird of South Africa. The long dark feathers trailing to the ground behind these birds are actually wing feathers, not tail feathers.
fun_facts:
The blue crane is one of only two species of crane without red on its head.
	The blue crane is the national bird of South Africa.

label: Goat
description: Goats are versatile domesticated animals kept for meat, milk and fiber. They are intelligent, social and difficult to herd. The Smithsonian's National Zoo exhibits Nigerian dwarf goats.
fun_facts:
A goat's eye has a rectangular pupil. It is believed that goats have excellent night vision.
	A goat's digestive system works nonstop throughout its adult life, continually manufacturing digestive juices and enzymes.

label: Ruppell's griffon vulture
description: The Rüppell's griffon vulture is the world's highest-flying bird. This critically endangered species is vital to Africa's ecology, flying long distances to eat carrion and keep ecosystems healthy.
fun_facts:
Rüppell's griffon vultures have been documented as having reached heights of over 36,000 feet (10,973 meters) above sea level. This discovery came at a cost; an individual was sucked into the engine of an aircraft flying at 36,100 feet (11,003 meters) above Cote d'Ivoire.
	The adaptation that allows this species to fly so high is an alteration of one of its proteins, which allows the bird to fly efficiently despite lower pressure and available oxygen.

label: Cheetah
description: A cheetah's slender body is built for speed. Accelerating from zero to 45 in just 2.5 seconds, it is the fastest land mammal and can reach top speeds of 60 to 70 mph (69 to 112 kilometers per hour). Cheetahs inhabit the African savanna but are vulnerable to extinction due to loss of habitat and limited genetic diversity.
fun_facts:
The cheetah is the single surviving species of the genus Acinonyx.
	A cheetah's footprints have claw tips visible, more like a dog's than like a typical cat's print.
	Cheetahs have very low levels of genetic variation compared to other mammals, making them susceptible to disease. This genetic similarity may have developed due to of a severe population reduction, or bottleneck, that occurred about 10,000 years ago.

label: Grevy's zebra
description: The largest of the zebra species, Grevy’s zebra have thicker stripes and bigger ears than other zebras. They are also the most threatened: fewer than 2,500 Grevy’s zebras may remain in the wild.
fun_facts:
Fossils found in China and Uzbekistan, as well as a two million-year-old fossil found in South Africa, suggest that ancestral forms of Grevy's zebras were once widespread in Africa and Eurasia.
	In 1882, Jules Grevy, the president of France, was given a zebra as a gift from the King of Abyssinia (what is now Ethiopia). A French zoologist realized that this type of zebra was different from other zebras and named the species after President Grevy.

label: Red River hog
description: Red rivers are the most colorful members of the pig family. They are an adaptable species found across west and central Africa.
fun_facts:
Red river hogs are also called "tufted pigs" due to their long, white whiskers and tufts found on the ears.
	They mark their territory, such as frequently used paths, using their tusks to scrape tree trunks, and using foot, neck and preorbital glands near their eyes to scent mark.

label: Scimitar-horned oryx
description: An elegant, graceful antelope — which may be behind the legend of the unicorn — the scimitar-horned oryx is supremely adapted to desert life. Currently extinct in the wild, conservation scientists are working on reintroduction programs in Tunisia, Chad and Niger.
fun_facts:
To deal with desert heat, scimitar-horned oryx can tolerate an internal body temperature of 116 degrees Fahrenheit (47 C). This allows them to conserve water and thrive in the desert.
	The scimitar-horned oryx is now extinct in the wild, though surveys show that Niger and Chad may have appropriate habitat for reintroduction, and some reintroductions have begun in Tunisia and Chad.

label: Sitatunga
description: The sitatunga is a swamp-dwelling antelope native to Africa. Its splayed feet make it an accomplished swimmer. Sitatungas spend the hottest parts of the day resting in the shade of reeds on platforms of dried plants, which they build themselves by circling and trampling on vegetation.
fun_facts:
Sitatunga are swamp-dwelling antelopes and excellent swimmers. Their elongated, wide-splayed hooves help them walk on soft terrain such as swamps and marshes.
	If seriously alarmed, sitatunga sink below water to swim to deeper areas with only their nostrils above the surface.

label: Lesser kudu
description: Lesser kudu are striking striped antelope native to the dry lands of northeastern Africa. Once gravely threatened by the rinderpest virus, their numbers are now rebounding.
fun_facts:
Like North American white-tailed deer, lesser kudus' tails are brown on top and white underneath and are held upright when the animal flees.
	Lesser kudu travel in impressive, bounding leaps, covering up to 30 feet (9 meters) at a time and reaching recorded heights exceeding 6.5 feet (2 meters).

label: Dama gazelle
description: The largest gazelle species, the critically endangered dama gazelle is also one of the rarest. Fewer than 400 individuals remain in the wild, mainly in Chad and Sudan.
fun_facts: Gazelles can often be observed bouncing into the air with all four hooves off the ground at the same time. This behavior is called stotting.

label: Ring-tailed lemur
description: Ring-tailed lemurs are named for the 13 alternating black and white bands that adorn their tails. Unlike most other lemurs, ringtails spend 40 percent of their time on the ground, moving quadrupedally along the forest floor.
fun_facts:
A ring-tailed lemur mob will gather in open areas of the forest to sunbathe. They sit in what some call a "yoga position" with their bellies toward the sun and their arms and legs stretched out to the sides. This position maximizes the exposure of the less densely covered underside of the lemurs to the sun, warming them up before they forage.
	Each ring-tailed lemur has exactly 13 alternating black and white bands on its tail.
	When ring-tailed troops travel throughout their home range, they keep their tails raised in the air, like flags, to keep group members together.

label: Schmidt's red-tailed monkey
description: The Schmidt’s red-tailed monkey — also called the black-cheeked white-nosed monkey, red-tailed guenon or Schmidt's guenon — is a small guenon characterized by a distinctive white or yellow nose, white cheeks and a long, red tail. These monkeys are native to central Africa and are threatened by hunting and deforestation.
fun_facts:
Schmidt's red-tailed monkeys have large cheek pouches that can store almost as much food as their stomachs.
	These monkeys are named for the red fur on their tails.

label: Siamang
description: Siamangs are arboreal inhabitants of the Malay Peninsula and Sumatran rain and monsoon forests. Their distinguishing feature is a large throat sac that they use to make socially important vocalizations. These primates are endangered due to illegal pet trade and habitat loss.
fun_facts:
Siamangs have a grayish or pinkish throat sac, which they inflate during vocalizations. The throat sac can become as large as a grapefruit.
	When moving slowly, they swing like a pendulum as they grab one branch and release before grabbing the next, so that the body is freely projected through the air. Flights of 25 to 32 feet (8 to 10 meters) have been witnessed.
	Siamangs are fiercely territorial and defend their territory with daily singing rituals.

label: Western lowland gorilla
description: Gorillas are the largest of the great apes, but the western lowland gorilla is the smallest of the subspecies. Native to the Congo Basin, the western lowland gorilla is a quiet, peaceful and nonaggressive animal threatened by disease and poaching.
fun_facts:
In addition to having distinctive fingerprints like humans do, gorillas also have unique nose prints.
	Gorillas are the largest of the great apes, but the western lowland gorilla is the smallest of the subspecies.

label: White-cheeked gibbon
description: Gibbons live in the evergreen tropical rainforests and monsoon forests of Laos, Vietnam and southern China. They are arboreal and spend most of their time in the forest canopy. White-cheeked gibbons are critically endangered, and their numbers have declined by 80 percent or more over the past 45 years, primarily due to habitat loss and poaching.
fun_facts:
Vocalization is a major social investment for white-cheeked gibbons. The basic pattern of gibbon vocalization consists of an introductory sequence where both males and females "warm up," followed by alternating sequences of male and female calls with female great calls. Vocalization sessions usually end with a male coda and are often accompanied by behavioral acrobatics.
	Gibbons move and feed mainly in the upper and middle levels of the canopy and almost never come down to the ground, except at the Zoo where they seem often to prefer to spend more time on the ground.

label: Andean bear
description: The Andean bear, or spectacled bear, is the only bear native to South America. It is a clever, arboreal animal that builds platforms and nests in trees for eating and sleeping.
fun_facts: The most arboreal bear species, spectacled bears will build platforms to reach food high in trees or nests to sleep in.

label: Brown pelican
description: A beautiful and unexpectedly graceful bird, brown pelicans live along both coasts of North America. Once threatened by DDT, they were one of the first species to recover from the effects of the pesticide and be removed from the Endangered Species List.
fun_facts:
While fishing, a brown pelican will fly up as high as 100 feet (30 meters), before folding back its wings and plunging into the sea. Brown pelicans are the only species of pelican that hunts with such dramatic plunging dives.
	In Florida, at least 500 pelicans are killed each year from entanglement in fishing gear, abandoned fishing lines, other marine debris and overhead wires.

label: Bald eagle
description: The bald eagle, the United States' national symbol, plummeted from abundance to endangered status; only 417 pairs were left in 1963. Thanks to tireless conservation efforts, this fish-eating raptor has rebounded and been removed from the Endangered Species List.
fun_facts:
Long, wide wings give bald eagles the ability to stay aloft and conserve energy by soaring.
	Keen, full-color vision is their most developed sense, which they use to find prey.

label: Beaver
description: Beavers are the largest rodents in North America and one of the few species that significantly modify their environment. By building watertight dams, which reduce stream erosion and form slow-moving ponds, they provide aquatic habitat for dozens of other species.
fun_facts:
Beavers are the largest rodents in North America and the second largest in the world (South America's capybaras being the heaviest).
	A beaver's teeth, which are orange due to their protective coating, grow continuously throughout its lifetime.
	Beavers do not have the ability to burp, but they can pass gas.

label: Gray wolf
description: Also called the timber wolf, gray wolves are the largest members of the canine family. Devoted parents and families, they are also among the most social carnivores. Once possessed of the greatest range of any terrestrial mammals except humans, they are now restricted in North America mainly to Alaska, Canada and wilderness in the northern United States.
fun_facts:
A maternal den, for mothers and pups, is one of the only ways that wolves seek shelter; otherwise, they are out in the open for most of their lives.
	Wolves are the largest canine, one of the most social carnivores and are a keystone species--critical to their ecosystems.
	More facts: Why Do Wolves Howl? And Other Top Questions Answered

label: Gray seal
description: Gray seals, also called horsehead seals, are amazingly dexterous swimmers. They are common on both sides of the north Atlantic.
fun_facts:
On land, seals move like caterpillars by alternately shifting weight from their chest to their pelvic region, or they roll to their destination. They appear quite clumsy and slow but can overtake a running human over a short distance.
	Seals see better underwater than above the surface.

label: California sea lion
description: Sea lions are large, gregarious mammals found along the western coast of North America. In the water, their torpedo-shaped bodies can reach speeds of 25 to 30 mph (40 to 48 kph).
fun_facts:
Unlike seals, sea lions primarily use their fore-flippers to propel themselves through the water. They also have visible ear-flaps, while seals only have ear holes.
	California sea lions may struggle with a tendency to overheat. To cool off, they will rest with a flipper in the water, flip sand over their backs or fan their flippers in the water.

label: Red-fronted lemur
description: Red-fronted lemurs are tree-dwelling animals about the size of a house cat. They live in Madagascar's deciduous forests and primarily eat fruit and leaves.
fun_facts: Lemurs establish and reinforce social bonds within groups through grooming. They have six lower teeth that stick straight out from the jaw, forming a dental comb used to groom their own fur and that of other members of their social group.

label: Norway rat
