description: The brown rat prefers to live almost anywhere humans are. Rats are foragers that can survive on a huge range of foods, which has helped them spread so successfully across the world. Humans often dislike rats, but rats present a variety of benefits to their ecosystems as predator and prey, are popular pets and have contributed to advances in the fields of genetics, cognitive research, physiology, epidemiology and pathology.
fun_facts:
Unlike cats, rats can move their whiskers. They are able to move each one individually. Rats use their whiskers much in the same way humans use their hands to feel and sense.
	Brown rats are foragers and can survive on a huge range of foods. One study of a rat's stomach contents revealed over 4,000 different items.
	Females experience a six-hour period of estrus, during which they mate as many as 500 times with multiple competing males.

label: Clouded leopard
description: Clouded leopards dwell in the cloud forests of Southeast Asia and are one of the most ancient cat species. However, they are neither a true great cat nor a true small cat, because they cannot roar or purr. Poaching and habitat loss threaten this vulnerable species.
fun_facts:
Clouded leopards can open their mouths to an impressive 100-degree angle!
	Clouded leopards are one of the few animals—and one of only two cat species—that can climb down trees headfirst.

label: Giant panda
description:
Native to central China, giant pandas have come to symbolize vulnerable species. As few as 1,864 giant pandas live in their native habitat, while another 600 pandas live in zoos and breeding centers around the world. The Smithsonian's National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute is a leader in giant panda conservation.

Ever since these charismatic bears arrived at the Zoo in 1972, animal care staff and scientists have studied giant panda biology, behavior, breeding, reproduction and disease. These experts are also leading ecology studies in giant pandas' native habitat. The Zoo's giant panda team works closely with colleagues in China to advance conservation efforts around the world.

fun_facts:
Though there are many theories, scientists are not certain why giant pandas have their distinctive black-and-white markings.
	Pandas are solitary animals but will vocalize during social interactions. They sometimes chirp, honk, bleat, chomp and bark.

label: Sloth bear
description: The shaggy-coated sloth bear is native to India, Sri Lanka and Nepal. Sloth bears primarily eat termites and ants, and unlike other bear species, they routinely carry their cubs on their backs.
fun_facts:
Sloth bears' nostrils can close completely, protecting the animals from dust or insects when raiding termite nests or beehives.
	Sloth bears are the only bears to routinely carry their young on their backs.

label: Asian small-clawed otter
description: Asian small-clawed otters are the smallest of all 13 otter species and are native to Asia. Well adapted to life in the water, these social, intelligent animals spend a majority of their time on land.
fun_facts:
Their coat of tightly packed under-fur and long guard hairs are water repellent. Air pockets within their coat keep them insulated and dry while under water, so it is very important that otters groom regularly and reintroduce air into their coats.
	Their ears are small and, like their nostrils, can be closed while the animal swims under water.

label: American bison
description: The largest terrestrial animals in North America, bison once roamed in herds numbering in the millions dominating prairie and forest ecosystems. Now reduced to a fraction of their current range and population, bison survive mainly in conservation herds.
fun_facts:
Bison have an excellent sense of hearing and smell, but cannot see very well, so an entire herd can stampede if it is startled. Bison have cloven hoofs, and can reach speeds of 30 miles per hour (48 kilometers per hour).
	Bison shed their heavy winter coats in the spring, rolling on the ground to loosen the hair, which falls off in gobs.

label: Fishing cat
description: Fishing cats are native to southern Asia. Very little is known about the behavior, habitat, population and habits of these elusive, nocturnal felines.
fun_facts:
Fishing cats are most closely related to Pallas cats, rusty-spotted cats, leopard cats and flat-headed cats.
	Unlike many cat species, fishing cats readily swim. Their front toes are partially webbed, and their claws protrude slightly even when retracted, an adaptation for fishing. Their round, elongated head is also adapted for diving.

label: Japanese giant salamander
description: Japanese giant salamanders are the second-largest salamander species in the world. These long-lived amphibians lurk in Japan's rocky, fast-flowing streams.
fun_facts:
Giant salamanders have amazing regenerative capabilities and are able to re-grow skin and bone.
	They are one of the largest salamander species in the world, second only to Chinese giant salamanders.
	Like other salamanders, they primarily "breathe" through their skin.

label: Allen's swamp monkey
description: Allen's swamp monkeys are small, stout monkeys with brown to gray fur and long tails. These highly social primates live in central Africa's swamp forests where they spend most of their time in trees. They are often hunted for bushmeat, killed in retaliation for crop raids and captured for the pet trade.
fun_facts:
Though they are largely arboreal, spending much of their time in the trees, these monkeys will occasionally come to the ground to forage.
	Allen's swamp monkeys are highly social primates that communicate with members of their troops using gestures and calls.

label: Black-and-white ruffed lemur
description: Black-and-white ruffed lemurs and red-ruffed lemurs are the largest in their family. Active during the day, and living mainly in trees, they are native only the Madagascar and critically endangered.
fun_facts: They have the unique ability among pollinators to open the traveler tree's flowers. While the lemurs benefit by eating the nectar within the flowers, the tree benefits from the pollination that occurs when the pollen sticks to the lemurs' faces and is transported to the next tree.

label: Land hermit crab
description: Land hermit crabs live close to the shoreline and must have access to both land and water. They are popular pets but do not breed in human care. Consequently, the pet trade harvests them from the wild, which is unsustainable.
fun_facts:
Hermit crab species come in a range of sizes, from a fraction of an inch to nearly the size of a coconut.
	A crab may eat its molted shell, possibly for its calcium, vitamins and minerals.

label: Gharial
description: The critically endangered gharial is easily distinguished from other crocodiles, because of the long, slender snout it shares only with the tomistoma (previously called the false gharial).
fun_facts:
The word gharial is derived from the word ghara, which means mud pot. It was misread by Europeans who changed the word to gavial. Thus, this species is known both as gavial and gharial.
	Gharial eggs are the largest of any crocodilian species, weighing on average 6 ounces (160 grams).

label: Harbor seal
description: Harbor seals, also known as common seals, spend half their time in the sea and half on land. They have the widest distribution of any seal and live in both the North Atlantic and Northern Pacific oceans. Harbor seals can be found anywhere from cool, temperate waters to cold, arctic and sub-arctic coasts.
fun_facts:
Harbor seals can dive to depths of 500 feet (152.4 meters) but depths of up to 1,460 feet (446 meters) have been recorded. They can remain submerged for up to 30 minutes at a time.
	Before a deep dive, harbor seals slow their heart rates from upwards of 80 (averaging between 80 and 120) beats per minute to as few as three or four. After surfacing, the seal's heartbeat accelerates rapidly for a short time.

label: Green anaconda
description: Green anacondas are one of the largest snakes in the world. Reports of anaconda attacks on humans are rare, but these boas can take down large prey, including jaguars.
fun_facts: Anacondas are a source of many myths that exaggerate their size and attacks on humans. Substantiated reports of giant constrictors actually killing and eating humans are quite rare.

label: Green salamander
description: Green salamanders live predominantly in wet, damp crevices and are the only salamander of the genus Aneides found in the eastern United States.
fun_facts: Green salamanders are largely inactive from about December to April.

label: Green tree python
description: Green tree pythons are named for their vibrant green color. These nonvenomous snakes and found in the tropical rainforests of New Guinea, eastern Indonesia, and the northeast Cape York Peninsula of Australia.
fun_facts:
In a phenomenon known as parallel evolution, green tree pythons looks and acts much like a South American relative, the emerald tree boa, to which it is not closely related. Though the resemblance in appearance and behavior is strong, there are significant differences as well. For instance, the boa bears live young, whereas the python lays eggs.
	Green tree pythons may have more than 100 teeth.

label: Hellbender
description: The eastern hellbender is the Americas’ largest salamander. Living in clean, swift-running rivers across the eastern United States, they spend their entire lives in the water. This near-threatened species is protected in several states.
fun_facts:
Hellbenders have lungs, but they are largely non-functional (vestigial). Instead hellbenders breathe using several loose flaps of thick wrinkled skin running along their sides. They absorb up to 95 percent of their oxygen through their skin, primarily through these folds and wrinkles.
	Mucus covers hellbenders' bodies, which may help protect them from abrasion and parasites. It is also distasteful to potential predators.

label: King cobra
description: King cobras are impressively venomous, large snakes native to Asia. They are called king cobras because they can kill and eat cobras.
fun_facts:
In the United States, research on cobra venom has yielded pain relievers such as Cobroxin, used to block nerve transmission and Nyloxin, used for severe arthritis pain.
	Snake charmers do not really hypnotize cobras with their flute music. It's often a sad con game in which an exhausted cobra is put on the defensive, yet conditioned (with pain) not to strike the flutist.

label: Komodo dragon
description: Komodo dragons, or Komodo monitors, are the largest, heaviest lizards in the world — and one of the few with a venomous bite. These stealthy, powerful hunters rely on their sense of smell to detect food, using their long, forked tongues to sample the air. They can spend hours waiting for a sizable meal to wander within range before launching a deadly attack with their large, curved and serrated teeth.
fun_facts:
Komodo dragons can briefly run at speeds of up to 13 mph (20 kph).
	When threatened, they can throw up the contents of their stomachs to lessen their weight in order to flee.

label: Long-tailed salamander
description: True to its name, the long-tailed salamander's tail takes up more than half of its body length. These salamanders are found along the eastern United States where they live in creek beds, caves, streams and ponds.
fun_facts: Long-tailed salamanders court by rubbing their heads together before mating.

label: Painted river terrapin
description: Dull in appearance for most of the year, painted terrapins actually get their name from their coloration during the breeding season when they acquire a vivid red stripe on their heads. Painted terrapins are critically endangered and native to the fresh and brackish waters of Southeast Asia.
fun_facts:
Painted terrapins cannot excrete salt from their bodies, which means they can live only in freshwater, or brackish water with low salinity.
	Compared to many other turtle species, the painted terrapin has a small clutch size (10 to 12 eggs). This, combined with a limited range of nesting beaches, makes it easier for poachers to find and capture individuals and collect their eggs.

label: Northern copperhead
description: The northern copperhead is a large, social, venomous snake found across the eastern United States in terrestrial and semiaquatic habitats.
fun_facts:
Even just-hatched copperheads have fully functional fangs capable of injecting venom that is just as toxic as an adult's venom.
	The copperhead is the cause of many snakebites yearly, but these bites are rarely fatal and typically occur when the snake is stepped on or accidentally touched.

label: Panamanian golden frog
description: The Panamanian golden frog is a tiny, brightly colored, frog-like toad native to the rainforests and cloud forests of Panama, though it is extinct in the wild. Its bright coloration warns predators of its overwhelming toxicity.
fun_facts:
Studies have shown that Panamanian golden frogs have enough toxins in their skin to kill more than 1,000 mice.
	They get their toxins from the insects they eat in the wild. The Zoo's golden frogs are fed different insects, so they are safe for keepers and researchers to handle.

label: Panamanian golden frog
description: The Panamanian golden frog is a tiny, brightly colored, frog-like toad native to the rainforests and cloud forests of Panama, though it is extinct in the wild. Its bright coloration warns predators of its overwhelming toxicity.
fun_facts:
Studies have shown that Panamanian golden frogs have enough toxins in their skin to kill more than 1,000 mice.
	They get their toxins from the insects they eat in the wild. The Zoo's golden frogs are fed different insects, so they are safe for keepers and researchers to handle.

label: Gila monster
description: Not monsters at all, Gila monsters are one of the few species of venomous lizards on the planet. These carnivores are classified as near threatened, and they are native to Arizona, California and Mexico.
fun_facts:
The Gila monster is one of only small number of venomous lizards (including the Mexican beaded lizard, the Komodo dragon and some Australian species).
	Rather than injecting venom through hollow fangs like venomous snakes, Gilas have enlarged, grooved teeth in their lower jaw. When they bite, their powerful jaws chew the venom in through capillary action along the grooves in these teeth.

label: Gaboon viper
description: The largest vipers in Africa, Gaboon vipers are lethargic and placid-natured. They only very rarely bite humans.
fun_facts:
Gaboon vipers are venomous. Their bite can be fatal, though they are calm and rarely bite humans.
	Their fangs can be 2 inches (5 centimeters) long, making them the longest fangs of any venomous snake.

label: Eyelash palm pitviper
description: One of the smallest venomous snakes in Central America, the eyelash palm pitviper is named for the bristly scales above its eyes.
fun_facts:
Eyelash palm pitvipers have inadvertently been sent throughout the world in banana shipments.
	Eyelash palm pitvipers are ovoviviparous, which means the eggs develop inside the mother, then hatch out and are apparently born.

label: North American river otter
description: The North American river otter is the most abundant otter species, but surprisingly little is known about its life in the wild. These otters are frequently observed playing and sliding together.
fun_facts:
While river otters tend to live alone or in pairs, they often socialize in groups and are known for their playful behavior.
	Otters are playful creatures, frequently seen sliding down riverbanks or burrowing through snow.

label: Hooded merganser
description: Hooded mergansers are ducks named for the white, fanlike crests that males have on their heads. These birds are the smallest North American mergansers. They breed in Canada and spend winters along coastal regions in the U.S.
fun_facts: Unlike other ducks, the hooded merganser almost always nests right next to water.

label: Common raven
description: Remarkably intelligent and social animals, ravens have been documented using tools. These omnivorous aerial acrobats range across much of the globe.
fun_facts:
Ravens are highly intelligent animals and can use their beaks to rip objects open, helping them find both food and shelter.
	Ravens have been known to use tools to obtain food and aid in defending their territories. Ravens and other corvid species are the subject of multiple cognitive research studies focusing on their ability to learn and use tools.

label: Aldabra tortoise
description: One of the world's largest land tortoises, Aldabra tortoises can reach sizes of up to 550 pounds and ages of up to 150 years old. They are native to Aldabra Island, one of the Seychelles northeast of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean.
fun_facts:
Aldabra tortoises are easily domesticated and can learn to identify their keepers in a short time.
	Aldabra tortoises can reach ages of over 150 years.

label: American alligator
description: Similar in appearance to the endangered American crocodile, alligators are not endangered. They range along waterways in the United States from North Carolina to Texas's Rio Grande.
fun_facts:
As an alligator's teeth are worn down, they are replaced. An alligator can go through 3,000 teeth in a lifetime.
	The sex of the juveniles is determined by the temperature of the eggs. Temperatures of 31 C (87.8 F) or below produce females, 32 C (89.6 F) produces 75 percent males and 32.5 C (90.5 F) and above are mostly females.

label: Burmese rock python
description: The largest subspecies of the Indian python, and one of the largest snakes in the world, Burmese pythons range throughout southeast Asia.
fun_facts: Burmese pythons swallow prey whole. Their jaws separate and allow them to eat an animal four to five times as wide as their heads.

label: Chinese alligator
description: A critically endangered cousin of the American alligator, it is one of the few alligators outside of the Americas. It is native to slow-moving freshwater areas of the lower Yangtze River in China where it eats snails, crustaceans, insects, fish, young waterfowl and rodents.
fun_facts: Chinese alligators dig extensive tunnels with multiple chambers, entrances and pools. Largely nocturnal because of human persecution, they stay in their tunnels much of the day when humans are in the vicinity, as well as during cool weather and winter months.

label: Cuban crocodile
description: One of the most endangered species of crocodile, the Cuban crocodile is now found only in a limited range in Cuba.
fun_facts:
Cuban crocodiles are strong swimmers and are adept at walking and leaping, which makes them equally at home in water or on land.
	Using powerful tail thrusts from below the water's surface, they can leap from the water to catch birds and mammals from overhanging tree branches.

label: Eastern indigo snake
description: Eastern indigo snakes are one of the largest North American snakes, reaching lengths of 5-7 feet. They are nonvenomous and found across the southeastern United States.
fun_facts:
Eastern indigo snakes are the longest snakes found in the U.S., reaching an average length of 5-7 feet.
	This snake is nonvenomous.

label: Eastern red-backed salamander
description: Lungless, eastern red-backed salamanders need to live in damp or moist habitats to breathe. They are native to the eastern United States and Canada.
fun_facts:
Eastern red-backed salamanders can evade predators by dropping all or part of their tail in the event of an attack. In its place, a new tail will eventually grow, though this new tail may be duller in color.
	Lifespan for the eastern red-backed salamander is approximately 25 years in human care.

label: Red panda
description: Red pandas, like giant pandas, are bamboo eaters native to Asia’s high forests. Despite these similarities and their shared name, the two species are not closely related. Red pandas are much smaller than giant pandas and are the only living member of their taxonomic family.
fun_facts:
Red pandas share the giant panda's pseudo-thumb, a modified wrist bone used to grasp bamboo when feeding.
	In very cold temperatures, red pandas can become dormant, lowering their metabolic rate and raising it every few hours as they wake up to look for food.
	Red pandas are the only living member of the family Ailuridae.
